PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President of the Senate and the Senators in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That in 1987/88 the Federal Government paid $6.4 million from taxpayers funds for 61,879 abortions under Medicare Items 6469 and 274/275 alone.
That in the same year Federal Government grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies and abolish Government funding of abortion.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Violent Television Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
We are concerned about the increase in violent television programmes for children and particularly those programmes promoting violent toys that are available for sale in Australia.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray; that you support the Broadcasting (Prohibition of Violent Programmes for Children) Act 1988 which has been presented by WA Independent Senator for Nuclear Disarmament, Jo Vallentine. This act aims to prohibit the broadcasting of children's TV programmes that are violent and that promote toys modelled on characters, weapons or other war accessories which are also available for sale in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Peace Trust Fund Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
At present all Australians, including those who conscientiously object to war and the preparation of war, are required by law for a portion of their income tax to be spent on military use.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you support the Peace Tax Trust Fund Bill 1989 which has been presented by Western Australian Independent Senator, Jo Vallentine. This Bill does not propose that anyone be permitted to withhold tax, but that the law should be changed to allow conscientious objectors to divert the military portion of their tax into more positive and socially useful programmes.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam: End of War List
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned showeth that:
The members of the Australian Armed Forces who served in Vietnam from 1962 to 1973 did so with distinction, valour and professionalism, upholding the traditions of the Armed Forces.
After World War 2 and the Korean War the Australian Government approved an End of War List of Gallantry Medals for individual acts of bravery that were not rewarded during wartime.
The Whitlam Government refused to approve such an End of War List at the end of the Vietnam War.

Your humble petitioners pray that the Federal Government reverse the decision of the Whitlam Government and thus approve an End of War List for the Australian Armed Forces Personnel that served in Vietnam.
Upon the approval of the End of War List, the case of the 2nd Lieutenant John Fraser, 3RAR be considered for the award of a posthumous military honour.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Home Ownership
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
Recent huge rises in mortgage interest rates have pushed the cost of buying their own home beyond the reach of most Australian families.

Those Australians already paying off home mortgages are now suffering severely and unfairly through increased mortgage payments or longer repayment times so that many will never pay off their mortgage and go further and further into debt unless interest rates fall substantially.

Now, therefore, your petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled require the Hawke-Keating government to cease its excessive reliance on high interest rates as its major economic policy weapon and instead to use other measures which would allow interest rates to return to levels that do not force most Australian home-seekers out of the housing market-and many home ownership is returned to average Australian families.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

(1) are opposed to the holding of an Arms Bazaar, AIDEX '89, at the National Exhibition Centre in Canberra on 28-30 November 1989

Pensions payable to, or in relation to, most former Commonwealth Government employees and Defence Force Personnel are increased in July each year in accordance with the increase in the weighted average of the consumer price index for the eight capital cities to the previous 31 March.

In 1986, the extraordinary circumstances of the economy required all members of the community to share the cost of reducing government expenditure. As part of these arrangements, the government legislated in October 1986 for the 2 per cent wage discount that had been applied to wages to be extended to the 1986 pension increase applied to government superannuation benefits payable to, or in respect of, former Commonwealth government employees and defence force personnel.

Since 1986 those pensions payable to former Commonwealth government employees and Defence Force Personnel have been adjusted by the full Consumer Price Index increase. Persons receiving those pensions have therefore suffered a significantly lower reduction in living standards than the average person in the workforce at the time when real wages for fulltime adult workers have fallen by 2.2 percent since 1982. In the context of the decision, announced in the April statement, to bring forward indexation increases of social welfare benefits by 12 weeks, the Government also decided that former Commonwealth government employees and Defence Force Personnel whose 1986 pension increases were reduced would have the level of those pensions restored from November 1989.

The purpose of this Bill is to implement the Government's decision. It amends the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Act 1973, the Defence Forces Retirement Benefits Act 1948, The Superannuation Acts 1922 and 1976 and The Papua New Guinea (Staffing Assistance) (Superannuation) Regulations to provide for the levels of pensions payable under that legislation to be increased from 20 October 1989. This is the first day in the pay period which ends on the first pension payday in November. Pensions will be increased from that date to the levels that would have applied if they had not been reduced in October 1986. The increase will be applied only to pensions directly or indirectly affected by the 1986 reduction.

It is expected that, as a result of the proposed amendments, total costs of the relevant pensions during 1989-90 will increase by approximately $17 million and during 1990-91 by approximately $27.7 million. Increases in outlays effects are estimated at $12.1 million for 1989-90, and $19.8 million for 1990-91.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, pursuant to my contingent notice of motion, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Chaney moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely, a censure motion relating to the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button).

Yesterday Senator Button responded to a series of questions from the Opposition on the issue of airline safety. We had a vintage performance from Senator Button which, once he came under a bit of pressure, turned into a series of abusive comments about the Opposition. He said that what was being raised by the Opposition:
. . . is yet another clear example of the despicable scaremongering that is being driven by the Opposition at the behest of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots.
There is apparently no limit to the depths to which Senator MacGibbon and his Opposition colleagues are prepared to descend to create panic and uncertainty in the minds of the travelling public.

That statement and an earlier statement in response to Senator MacGibbon, which was in similar terms, questioning the motives of the Opposition and questioning the facts which were raised by us earlier in Question Time, were part of what has come from the Government, namely, a series of bland reassurances about the standards which are being maintained by this Government. In the House of Representatives at the same time a number of questions were put to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis). At the same time as we were getting bland assurances from Senator Button, interspersed with some abuse about the motivation of the Opposition, Mr Willis was telling the House of Representatives that he was aware of allegations made by the Australian Federation of Air Pilots and various of its supporters, including the Federal Opposition, that the Civil Aviation Authority has compromised safety during this dispute. He said:
I totally reject that charge. Both the Government and the CAA are concerned to ensure that, in rebuilding our domestic aviation system, Australia's high safety standards are fully maintained.
A little later in the same answer he said:
There has been no change to the normal requirement that pilot competence must be adequately demonstrated.

It is all part of a pattern of reassurance, Mr President, at a time when, as Minister Button admitted in the Senate yesterday, the air services of Australia are under considerable stress. The stress must be evident when we look at the description of the air services being provided under this Government which was provided to the Estimates Committee just two days ago. The normal company aircraft which provide services around Australia at the moment are providing 29 per cent of the capacity; leased aircraft, which are substantially foreign aircraft, are providing in excess of that; and the rest is made up of foreign carriers, Royal Australian Air Force and Royal Australian Navy flights and commuter flights.

During this period of stress it has been of concern to the Opposition to ensure that the safety standards of which Australians are justifiably proud-those of us who fly frequently are extremely grateful for them-should not be compromised. The first matter that was raised with me was raised by Senator Panizza. He raised an issue which had come to his direct attention because of his own experience on a charter flight. The matters that were raised by Senator Panizza, by Senator Brian Archer and by a series of senators in this place have been pooh-poohed by the Government and we have been told that there is nothing to worry about. We have been told that the matter is simply a political gambit on the part of the Opposition.

That position is very hard for the Government to sustain, in the face of the revelation that senior officials in the Civil Aviation Authority who are concerned with the maintenance of safety standards have now been shown to have made complaints to their senior officers over what they see as the very serious breaches of safety standards which have occurred over the weeks of this dispute. I hope that Senator Button was able to watch some television this morning because on Good Morning Australia there was a public servant from the Civil Aviation Authority, an airworthiness surveyor named Mr Quinn, putting on the public record in the most open way possible his concerns. In the interview he made it clear what his judgment of the safety situation was when he said he was going to drive back to Melbourne rather than fly. I suppose for someone as intimately involved in the administration of safety standards as he is that is a fairly telling comment.

What Mr Quinn described in that interview this morning is the sort of factual situation which gives rise to the concern of the Opposition and leads us to wish to debate this matter now and to censure the Leader of the Government for his cavalier attitude to this serious matter and for his abusive response to serious matters which were raised with him yesterday. Mr Quinn in his interview talked about finding structural cracks, unacceptable levels of corrosion, brakes worn beyond limits, fluid systems with unaccept- able leaks and aircraft flying without maintenance releases. This is the description given by one of the people charged with the responsibility of seeing that aircraft standards are maintained.

A little later in the same interview we found Mr Quinn telling the Australian people that the Authority cannot even get access to the foreign aircraft which are being brought in with the active encouragement of this Government and which are being used to provide the great bulk of air services which the Australian people are using. Mr Quinn said:

. . . we have been given written direction that we are not to board those aircraft, we have no right to board those aircraft although we have informally walked around them. But we haven't carried out a surveillance or an assessment on aircraft as such.
He went on to say:
. . . one aircraft which is not flying by the way, I must stress that, we walked around and we found that the main landing gear support . . . was cracked. But that aircraft has not been flown.

That is an example of one person who has been prepared to go to the public and to disclose what he regards as a situation so unsatisfactory that he himself is choosing to drive rather than fly to Melbourne from Canberra.

A far more comprehensive description of what is wrong with the system that is being operated has become public over the last 12 hours. Indeed, a number of major newspapers have reported on the reports from within the Civil Aviation Authority which go to operational standards and to concerns among senior officials about those operational standards. It is in that context that the Opposition seeks the suspension of Standing Orders because we have taken a number of steps to try to ensure that the Government maintains standards. We have sought, for example, a parliamentary committee which will examine that aspect of the Civil Aviation Authority's administration. The Government has undertaken to discuss that matter with us; it has not closed the door on it although my meeting with Minister Willis was cancelled at 9 o'clock this morning and I suppose he has other things on his mind. Our persistent concern is to ensure that these matters are addressed early so that an accident or accidents can be avoided.

SPEECH.PARA: The events of recent weeks have had a deleterious effect on our ability to set and administer standards for the airline industry. We have:
granted concessions, for purely political reasons, against longstanding requirements without due consideration of the equivalent safety factors;

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate censures the Leader of the Government for his failure to give proper consideration to concerns about air safety raised by the Opposition in light of the grave concern at senior levels of the Civil Aviation Authority about current procedures and standards and condemns the Minister for his despicable allegation of improper motives and scaremongering in the Opposition's questioning of safety issues arising from the pilots' dispute.

Some of the matters which I wish to address in this motion have been addressed in the motion to suspend Standing Orders, but let me say that the complaint which we specifically address to Senator Button goes to his response yesterday to a series of questions which were addressed to him on the issue of airline safety. In response to the matters which were put to him Senator Button said-I have already quoted these words-that it was another example of despicable scaremongering driven by the Opposition at the behest of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots.

Let me concentrate my remarks now on the remarks which are made not by the Federation of Air Pilots but by officials of the Civil Aviation Authority. Again, I will not repeat the comments made by Mr Quinn, the aircraft examiner, this morning, except to remind the Senate that a restriction upon Australian bureaucrats actually inspecting foreign aircraft does seem to me to be the height of absurdity. Let me simply use the words which have been used, as I say, not by politicians, not by airline pilots, but by people like Mr Segan, the senior examiner for the Civil Aviation Authority, and Mr Lewino, who is the General Manager for Victoria and Tasmania for the Civil Aviation Authority. Mr President, these are simply some extracts from the documents which at this stage I have not tabled although I intend to do so at the conclusion of this speech unless some good indication has been given to me as to what sections are objected to. What was said by Mr Segan was:
We had a basic duty to our employer, the public, to maintain standards and in this area I believe we have been totally inadequate.

He went on then in this report to deal in great detail with the sorts of inadequacies which have caused him to say that the standards have not been maintained but concessions have been granted for purely political reasons without due consideration of equivalent safety factors. Apparently, there have been a series of concessions made with respect to the admission of new pilots and aircraft for domestic use in Australia. What this report says under the heading of `granting concessions' is:

A major error was to allow ourselves to be drawn into discussions with airline commercial management-a group who had no knowledge or interest in standards. Their approach was to attack our standards in an attempt to reduce training requirements and they were successful. Their only negotiating point was the threat of ministerial action and it is an indication of our lack of confidence that we did not call their bluff. As a result new standards were set by political blackmail and it is now highly unlikely that we can redeem this situation.

Mr President, the report goes on to deal with the fact that foreign pilots have been accredited to fly without supervision in Australia. Under that heading we find that there are concerns about, for example, the French pilots who have been admitted. That concern, which is in a sense expressed in an academic way in this report, is borne out by the incident which was raised by Senator MacGibbon in the Senate yesterday and which was the subject of the paper which I have incorporated in Hansard and tabled earlier today. Mr Segan says:
It is an acknowledgment that the company procedures and practices detailed in the operations manual are well known to that pilot.
That is the requirement that he fly under supervision for up to 50 hours. Mr Segan continues:
This cannot be said of the French-indeed, it could be argued that their difficulty with the English language would override any advantage that their type endorsement may have offered.

He then expresses criticisms of the flight rules and procedures examination. Normally Australian pilots are required to sit examinations at various levels and each of these examinations is given in series. He says:

With the French pilots this was not done and what amounted to a re-typed, open book SCPL paper given purely to expedite licence issue. Small wonder, therefore, that within a week of the commencement of their operation we should have reports of ATC confusion due to non standard radio calls, and of RPT aircraft turning right in left hand traffic patterns.
He talks about English language tests:
This Authority has a requirement to check all pilots whose first language is not English prior to the issue of a licence . . . To my knowledge no such testing occurred.
Examination Reset Frequency.

The Authority had a policy on the time interval which should have elapsed before an unsuccessful candidate could reset a written examination. This situation is quite defensible. We possessed a limited number of papers and the aim was to have the candidate acquire the necessary knowledge through study rather than to memorise exam questions. This policy was relaxed without justification even before the French pilots had sat their first exam.
He complains about the approval of British Aerospace check captains. He says:

There is no evidence whatsoever to indicate that the pilots on loan from British Aerospace possess the necessary knowledge of CAA requirements and Company operations manual procedures to satisfactorily complete these checks which hitherto were the province of a very select group of senior pilots. Our approval of these on-loan pilots as unrestricted check captains cannot be justified.

He goes on and refers to the misuse of regulatory powers and says that the intent of the regulations has been ignored although the letter has been acknowledged. He considers that the approval of certain Aero Maritime aircraft is `nothing more than a cynical exercise in rule bending'. Then there are extensive references to the approval of Captain Smith as a check captain, and that is the matter which is the subject of the very lengthy memorandum from Mr Lewino to which I have earlier referred. This officer said:

. . . the Company was desperate to put pilots on the line. Given the circumstances, there was no way that Radnedge could have afforded to fail [Smith] on that check. I firmly believe we should have despatched a regular examiner to observe Radnedge's conduct of the check.
That is the check on Captain Smith. He continued:

Further to the above, Captain [Smith's] performance since assuming office in the West has fallen well short of expectations. There would now appear to be ample evidence that Smith has difficulty in reconciling his loyalty to the Ansett commercial operation with his obligations as the delegate of the Authority. One of our concerns was [Smith's] insistence in bypassing the recognized chain of command within the Ansett check and training system in an attempt to reduce training requirements. It was for these reasons that I elected to delay written confirmation of check approval pending further observations of his performance by both our examiner and Ansett check and training staff. The decision, therefore, by Central Office staff to issue [Smith's] approval in the face of Field Office concern was disappointing.
He referred to the breakdown of Civil Aviation Authority communications and said:

Central Office staff appear to have been stampeded into offering instant policy decisions and these have been conveyed directly to the airlines leaving Field Office staff completely out of loop. Airline management has been quick to identify this weakness and has successfully played both officers against each other talking directly to whoever they considered would provide the most favourable response. The result has been the degradation of long established standards.
The summary of this officer was as follows:
The events of recent weeks have had a deleterious effect on our ability to set and administer standards for the airline industry. We have:

granted concessions, for purely political reasons, against long standing requirements without due consideration of equivalent safety factors; interpreted the literal translation of Regulations solely to expedite approvals without taking due consideration of the intent of such legislation; and allowed a major communication breakdown to develop such that logical and considered decisions could no longer be guaranteed.

That was the statement of one senior officer of the Civil Aviation Authority. Let me refer to a memo which was sent to Mr Freeland, the head of that Authority, and to other senior officers by Mr Lewino. I simply wish to give a number of direct quotes from that report which I think summarise the concerns which now must be addressed as a matter of urgency by the Government. He says:

The current pilot dispute has seriously weakened the Ansett operational organisation, despite the fact that a number of the more senior operational managers remained with the company. For political and industrial reasons, Ansett needs to keep at least a token airline service in operation and has used its remaining management pilot force to fly these aircraft. However, people cannot be in two places at once, and as a result experienced operational managers have not been available to organise and oversight developments, such as the introduction of foreign charter services and the reactivation of Ansett services with foreign crews.
A little later he says:

A more serious consequence, which has manifested itself over the last week, is that the operational managers are becoming fatigued. They are flying to the full limit of flight and crew duty rules (in one case, over these limits). . .
A little later he says that a particular named individual stated that `working to the prescribed limit was very tiring for management pilots and he could not accept any increase'. He continues:
There is other evidence of fatigue. Normally, cool calm managers are becoming terse and brusque and they look tired. People like . . . . . seem to have aged several years.

He talks about a captain brought over from New Zealand to head the program of training for French-Hungarian BAe146 pilots. He says that `the only concern about' that individual `at that stage was advice from' another official from the Civil Aviation Authority `that he had a known history at deliberately breaking rules'. He goes on to say:
In particular, he had been approved to give a demonstration flight at an air show and had exceeded to safety limitation laid down in the approval.

He talks about that officer's reacting `precipitously and with emotional aggression'. He talks about-and I referred to this in the debate on my motion to suspend Standing Orders-the contact with Ansett Airlines via the Willis office and the clear close involvement of the Government in these arrangements. He talks again about the named officer's unreliability and about two training flights with a French pilot for whom he was asked to issue a certification of validation to captain of BAe146 aircraft, which he declined to do. Subsequent observation of that pilot's performance by another examiner captain confirmed that he was not at that time up to command status. The same named individual sought the right to carry out his duties as a supervising pilot or as an observer by using the observer seat on the flight deck with two French first officers occupying the pilots' seats in order to expedite their training.
Again I declined-
this is the officer speaking-
and expressed my amazement that he could propose such a course of action, particularly on a revenue flight carrying members of the public.

What is being described there is an attempt to institute a procedure by somebody who has the responsibility of supervising the introduction of foreign pilots and who is seeking not to sit in the copilot's seat or in the captain's seat but to sit in the observer seat while two foreign pilots fly a commercial flight with a full commercial load. That is the sort of allegation that is being made, not by the Opposition, but by officials within the Civil Aviation Authority. When we contrast that with the responses that have been received in the Senate, giving clear assurances that the procedures have been maintained, it is absolutely clear that we have a very serious problem which needs immediate attention.

Our concern in this motion is to record the Senate's disapproval of a situation where the senior Minister in this place, Senator Button, is not only a party to bland reassurances about safety, which at best would have to be said to be highly questionable, but is in turn abusive of the Opposition for raising matters that are obviously of central public interest. In our view, Senator Button should be censured by the Senate. Most importantly, the Government should act on this safety issue.

SPEECH.PARA: The next document which Senator Chaney cites in retrospective support of his allegation of my conduct yesterday is the document prepared in the Victorian-Tasmanian division. The document from Mr Segan concerns a number of matters. I want to make a comment about it. Subsequent to the recommendations of the Aviation Safety Regulatory Review Committee earlier this year, the CAA had for some time been revising its regulatory approach to concentrate on the outcome of safety rather than rigid means of getting there. I interpolate that a committee has been looking at the operations of the CAA and the Federal Airports Corporation. In the course of that committee inquiry Opposition senators have challenged the CAA about being insufficiently flexible and being too rigid in the procedures which it adopts. The CAA has responded to those expressions of concern. The accusation against it has been that it is too rigid and insufficiently flexible. TALK.START.PARA: —That was one of them.
—There was another element which Mr Quinn referred to in terms of his personal wishes about travel.
—And the inspection results on domestic planes.

—Yes. In respect of the question of foreign aircraft airworthiness, let me make this point: foreign aircraft airworthiness is the responsibility of the foreign regulatory authority. America West aircraft, for example, which are currently flying in Australia, are subject to a continuous airworthiness maintenance program approved by the Federal Aviation Authority (FAA) operating in the United States. This program describes what must be done in terms of maintenance and airworthiness, and when and how. Compliance is the responsibility of the aircraft operation. Surveillance is the responsibility of the appropriate regulatory authority-in this case, the FAA. Three weeks ago the FAA stated its position on airworthiness and on operations inspections in Australia to assist the CAA to ensure that appropriate airworthiness arrangements were in place. The CAA is in constant communication with a number of foreign regulatory authorities to ensure that safety is not compromised.

SPEECH.PARA: The airworthiness arrangements for these planes operating in Australia are exactly the same as those applying to any international airline normally operating in Australia on which thousands upon thousands of Australians have travelled with utmost safety for many years. That is the position that the CAA, as the appropriate regulatory authority, adopts. That is consistent with the position always adopted in respect of foreign aircraft flying in Australia. Any questions that have been asked here have been answered and they have been answered on advice from the appropriate body to handle these matters, the Civil Aviation Authority. That is the regulatory authority in Australia. It is an organisation with a hierarchial structure, it is an organisation in which officers at more junior levels are entitled to put views about particular situations to management and, as I have already said, it is an organisation in which on occasions the advice of those more junior officers in the region has been acted on. So to say that there has been a bland brushing off in this chamber of questions which have been put about air safety is incorrect. Questions have been asked and answers have been given.

It is quite correct to say that at the present time the airline system is operating under difficult circumstances. The Government does not retreat from that issue at all, but in those difficult circumstances the responsible authority, the CAA, has been very diligent in ensuring that safety standards have been maintained, although procedures may have been expedited or altered in some minor way in order to cope with a very difficult situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is nonsense.

—It is not nonsense at all. As Senator Ray said before, all that stuff debases their coinage. That has been part of the Opposition's desperate efforts to manoeuvre some political advantage out of a very difficult situation for the airlines and those associated with them.

SPEECH.PARA: Another allegation which Senator Chaney made was that I was rude to the Opposition yesterday. I want to come back to that because it is of some concern to me. I just want to establish the circumstances in which I was rude to the Opposition. I think that the honourable senator used the word `offensive'. All those words flow readily off his tongue and I am not sure which one he used yesterday or today. That is the substance of the allegation and it is to be found in part of the censure motion itself. It was said that I made despicable allegations of improper motives in the Opposition. I will repeat what I said yesterday lest there be any misunderstanding about this. Everybody in this chamber, Government and Opposition senators alike, are legitimately concerned about air safety issues at all times, but Senator MacGibbon phrased a question regarding an alleged incident at Sydney in these terms:

Is the Minister aware that, despite urgent calls from an alert Sydney traffic control, the pilots persisted with their error? What disciplinary action has been taken against these pilots? Not only could there have been a collision between two commercial airliners with great loss of life, but the accident could have occurred over southern suburban Sydney, possibly over a school, and even more lives could have been lost.

The despicable allegation that I made yesterday, which I repeat today, was that that was a loaded question, that it was scaremongering calculated to attract a headline somewhere or other, but that it was remote from the truth because the incident which Senator MacGibbon was referring to occurred 50 miles south of Wollongong. There was only one aircraft in the region; there was no possibility of a collision. There was no concern by the Civil Aviation Authority that there was a possibility of a collision.

Opposition senators must understand that the nature of a question is to elicit information; it is not to assert scaremongering remarks like that. It is, in my view, a despicable misuse of Question Time to try to raise a headline somewhere or frighten people. There have been other incidents of this. That is what is objected to by the Government. In respect of every serious question that has been asked and which has sought a serious answer, an answer has been obtained from the Civil Aviation Authority or any other appropriate authority.

This censure motion has two parts. Firstly, it says that the Opposition is more concerned about air safety than anybody else. In the six weeks of the air pilots dispute we have tried everything in the chamber: we have tried backing the pilots and backing away from the pilots; we have tried backing the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and backing away from the Commission. Every week it has been a case of to and fro. Every week there has been a different tactic but none of them has worked. The Opposition has had a golden opportunity to prove its industrial relations policy. It has failed. It has done nothing that has been of any interest in terms of the very difficult situation in the airlines.

This week has been safety week. So we have had a whole series of questions about safety and those questions have been answered. The understood procedure in Question Time is that one asks a question and one gets an answer either the same day or the next day. But the real nub of this censure motion is that I got up Senator Chaney's nose yesterday by telling him that 21 per cent of the business community say that they understand and approve of the Liberal Party industrial relations policy. After seven weeks of the pilots strike he has a golden opportunity to explain it all.

I do not for a moment retreat from what I said about Senator MacGibbon. It is all very well to have legitimate concerns about issues and I am sure that there are plenty of Opposition senators and people on the Government who do. The Opposition has no monopoly of concern about many of these issues. But to try to turn concerns into fears and headlines in the course of a question is the sort of thing which I object to and find despicable. I will probably get another censure motion tomorrow for saying, as I did yesterday, that I find that sort of conduct reprehensible. Well, we will be ready for it when it comes. Perhaps tomorrow the honourable senator will have another document-a bit of new material. But this censure motion should be rejected because, in the current circumstances, it is ridiculous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not support this censure motion. As the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) has already said, it is scaremongering. It is cheap scaremongering. If we ask any comedian how to make a quick joke the comedian will tell us, `Make a joke about flying' because people are afraid of flying. They are afraid of getting their feet off the ground. It is a basic fear. One of the reasons that our pilots are paid so much and are considered God-like is that people who do not fly very much want to consider these pilots as someone above the mortal plane so that they can take care of their lives in the air. The fact is that Bob Newhart has made a profession out of fear of flying jokes and now the Opposition has tried to hang on to this coat-tail and sell its scaremongering on the subject of safety. In fact, flying is 400 times safer than driving a car. More people are killed in bathtub accidents than in flying accidents. Flying is basically a safe operation and it is still safe in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are seeing is the Opposition buying into a fight between the conservative old guard bureaucrats in the Civil Aviation Authority and the reform minded CAA leadership. As Senator MacGibbon would agree, the CAA has been a turgid and constipated bureaucracy fraught with rules and regulations. The new CAA, over the last 12 months, has been trying to break through this morass of red tape and get Australia flying safely, and that is the bottom line-safety. The old time bureaucrats have been hiding behind this shibboleth of safety and building their empires on the basis of `safety'. But these rules are not safe; they are not necessarily safe. I have read the letters that Senator Chaney has tabled and quoted from. What I see and hear is basically the old guard bureaucrat saying `Hey, we don't want to change our procedures. We like the old procedures. We like that red tape'. Let me tell the Senate how much it takes for a pilot to come here under the old system and fly in Australia. As a commercial pilot I came from the United States to fly in Australia. I was made to go through a student pilot exam, a restricted pilot exam and an unrestricted pilot exam.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you pass?

—Many people advised me that I could not do it. An Australian pilot in America can fly on the day that he arrives in America. An Australian pilot in Britain, France or anywhere else can do the same, because the standards of the world are applied. Only in Australia were these standards not applied. The CAA is bringing Australia into line with the rest of the world. Some of these very frightened bureaucrats are using this safety issue and this strike issue to try to preserve their own bureaucratic empires. Frankly, I do not want to go along with that. I do not really think that the Opposition and Senator MacGibbon would like to go along with that, either.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at some of the things that have been mentioned. What about this famous telex? The telex said that an aircraft turned right and did not respond to the radar operator, or whatever it was. I have not really had a chance to read the telex. I would say that that is more a result of this same turgid constipation in our regulations than anything else. From memory, there are 84 standard instrument departures for Sydney airport. That means that each pilot has to go through a great sheaf of literature to figure out how to depart Sydney airport. That is because of the proliferation of regulations.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many out of Los Angeles?

—Four out of Los Angeles, Senator. In fact, the CAA has just sent some representatives overseas to look at this very thing with the goal of simplifying the procedures at Sydney airport. So any pilot, French or not, can get into trouble in Sydney or anywhere else under this system. I have a friend, a commercial pilot, a jet rated pilot who worked for the Hobart flight service. When he flew to Melbourne he would request radar control into Essendon rather than into Moorabbin, the general aircraft field, because it was too complicated-and he was a flight service officer.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the extent of the regulations which exist in this country. The CAA presently is trying to cut through them. Of course it is meeting resistance. People do not like to change their ways. That is really the bottom line of these letters. Now let us take a look at them in some detail; we have heard bits of them. On one page of the first letter which is from Mr Segan, it says:
We have . . . interpreted the literal translation of Regulations solely to expedite approvals without taking due consideration of the intent of such legislation . . .
He is trying to get it both ways here. He is saying, `We should stick to the regulations', but if we do he does not like it. I think he is protecting his empire directly.

Let us go to another letter which was from Mr Lewino. It is the second letter which has been quoted. It is headed `Report on Ansett Airlines operational standards with particular reference to Ansett Western Australia'. Basically, what this involves is the fact that an experienced BAE146 check pilot, Captain Colin Smith, was brought over from New Zealand to head a program of training. This apparently got up the nose of the local Australian CAA officials. The letter states:
The only concern about Captain Smith at that stage was advice from Mr Scaife AGM (SR) in WA, that he had a known history-
a known history; we should watch his terminology--
at deliberately breaking rules. In particular, he had been approved to give a demonstration flight at an air show and had exceeded the safety limitation laid down in the approval.

Wow! Is that not awful? Maybe they gave him permission to do one loop and he did two. It could be on that basis. I have been involved myself in air shows. I know the permission a pilot has to get in air shows and I know they will throw the book at him if he does not follow the letter of the law in the permission they gave him. Once again, this relates to an adherence to regulations. The person who wrote this letter is showing his hate for Captain Smith because Captain Smith is a rule breaker-he once broke a rule at an air show. The letter goes on in that vein. The penultimate page of Mr Lewino's letter states:

I must also record my assessment of the likely adverse effects of Mr Thomas' decision on staff morale and the reputation of the CAA. The RPT Examiners involved in the safety assurance of airline operational standards have been required to make major adjustments to their normal practices.

Oh my goodness! We have asked a bureaucrat to make a major adjustment to his normal practices. What a terrible thing! Has a censure motion been launched on that? Long established requirements have been cut back to expedite the return of regular public transport services. Those long established requirements were being cut back anyway, before the airline strike. These people are objecting to having to change their ways and act in a responsible manner towards the taxpayers of Australia. I am sure these people have legitimate concerns in their own minds but to a person who has some familiarity with the aircraft industry I find that they are merely trying to cling to the old ways which have so disadvantaged the airline industry in Australia.

We have an interview, which I did not see, by a Mr Quinn. He said that because of lack of proper maintenance and too many flying hours apparently the CAA has found unacceptable levels of corrosion and cracks. Unacceptable levels of corrosion simply could not happen in the last six weeks. Corrosion is something that happens over a period of years. Here is Mr Quinn running out and saying, `Corrosion because of the airline strike'. What a bunch of nonsense. I will not delay the chamber very much longer but I would like to point out that what we have here is an unholy alliance of the Opposition parties, the airline pilots who, of course, are trying to push their own barrow and some very conservative bureaucrats who simply do not want to change with the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who didn't get their own way.

—They did not get their own way; they lost. I feel that this censure motion is absolutely fatuous. We ought not be looking at this very sacred shibboleth of air safety which has been used over and over again to justify all sorts of injustices. We should look at ways of resolving the pilots strike directly. If the Opposition is really interested in resolving the pilots strike, if the Senate is interested in resolving the strike, how about a Senate select committee not on some narrow trumped up issue of safety but on the strike itself, to report very quickly, in three weeks? Could the Senate not be considered to be an honest broker? I hesitate to use the word.
—Why did you have to pause?

—I am sorry. But perhaps the Senate could be an honest broker. Senate select committees, which involve all parties, have a good reputation. I think our committee system is one of the best parts of the whole Senate operation. I suggest we set up a select committee to look into the airline strike in a bipartisan or non-partisan way to examine all the issues, including safety, and perhaps resolve this terrible strike which is so affecting our country. But to narrowly focus on one issue of safety and to do it in the manner in which the Opposition has done is not only non-productive; it is counterproductive. It avoids the main issues and the Australian Democrats will certainly not support this action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it a motion to censure Senator Button for his actions in relation to his personal conduct and his lack of responsibility in handling the elements of safety which have been a consequence of the airline pilots strike which is now before Australia. Senator Button has not honoured the trust placed in him by the Australian public in the office he holds. He has not honoured the responsibilities vested in him to seriously maintain the safety of the Australian travelling public. That is the whole burden of our argument. He has been guilty of gross irresponsibility and a dereliction of his professional duties in this matter, and he demonstrated that in that collection of trivia that passed for the speech that he made in his own defence this morning.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me deal very briefly with that speech. It arose out of an answer to a question that I asked on Tuesday. Yesterday Senator Button came into the Senate and gave a nonsensical answer. It was nonsensical-I quote from the Hansard pinks-in that Senator Button said, `The aircraft had planned to fly from Wollongong via Shelley, to Corryong and thence to Melbourne'. Now there are only four standard instrument departures off runway 16 at Sydney. Two go via Wollongong; two go via Shelley. One cannot be in two places at the same time. One cannot be going east and west simultaneously. That answer, which obviously came from the Department of Transport and Communications, was either the product of ignorance or intentionally designed to mislead. Senator Button is guilty of misleading the Senate with that fatuous answer.

In his speech Senator Button attacked the members of the Senate who raised legitimate questions about safety. He said, `This motion this morning is not about safety; it is about the abuse of the Opposition'. That is not our case at all. He went on to say that the document expresses some concerns raised within the Department. I agree, and we agree, that the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) has been placed under enormous stress through the pilots strike, but the important thing that concerns the Opposition is that the Civil Aviation Authority has failed under those stresses. That is, it has failed to maintain the standards of safety for the Australian public, which is its raison d'etre.

Senator Button dealt with the letter by Mr Lewino, the Assistant Regional Director of the Victorian-Tasmanian division of the Civil Aviation Authority. Senator Button claimed it was centred on the certification of British Aerospace pilots as check captains for British Aerospace 146 aircraft. If Senator Button takes the time to read Mr Lewino's letter he will find that that is not the central point of the argument at all. He made the point that the Civil Aviation Authority is changing, that it is more concerned with the outcomes of safety than the means of getting there. We have no quarrel on this side of the Parliament with the need for change within the Civil Aviation Authority. But we object violently when that change is brought about as a result of political pressure by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) looking after his mates, Mr Harris and Sir Peter Abeles, and the airlines that they represent. We do not mind change if it is reasoned and rational but we object very much to the sheer political pressures that have been placed on the Civil Aviation Authority to bring about change.

The thing that really infuriated Senator Button and caused him to lose control totally in the chamber yesterday was my allegation that an accident could have happened. Senator Button, that is where-he is laughing as I say this-this charge sticks. He has no sense of responsibility. He is a pygmy in that regard. He does not recognise the responsibilities vested in him in the office he holds. Accidents happen. The tragic thing about what is happening in Australia today is that the system that prevents our having accidents is being debased by this Government. In other words, the tragedy that could befall us is quite preventable. It is the dereliction of duty by Senator Button and his colleagues in the Cabinet that is the really shocking thing about what is happening today. The Opposition believes that there is abundant evidence that the safety of the Australian travelling public has been put gravely at risk.

Neither I nor Senator Chaney is censuring Senator Button for his lack of knowledge about the Civil Aviation Authority. We do not mind that he does not know the details of questions. I recognise more than anyone the arcane, Byzantine world of the Civil Aviation Authority. It is like no other authority in Australia. It deals with aviation and has its own sets of rules, its own procedures, which are not paralleled in any other form of activity within this country. Unless one has been exposed to them, and unless one has worked under them, one simply does not understand how the aviation regulatory system in this country works.

I have been interested in aviation all my life and I have been a pilot for more than 25 years. I have owned aircraft for over 20 years. I have always tried to understand and become involved with the regulatory functions through the Department of Aviation, the Department of Civil Aviation and now the Civil Aviation Authority. I do not pretend to have a knowledge that is in any way complete but I do say categorically that I have a better knowledge about how the Civil Aviation Authority works than anyone else in this Parliament. I put on record my respect and admiration for the officers of the Authority who have served under what have been incredibly trying circumstances under this Labor Government. The only censure I have is for its senior officers, who I will come to later. They have not looked after the men and women working for them lower down the line and taking responsibility.

The whole matter of aviation safety is not a matter of legislation. It is a cultural thing. Aviation involves three dimensions, unlike every other form of human activity which involves two dimensions. We have learned some lessons about aviation. We have learnt how to operate safely in the air but it has taken us about 70 years and thousands of lives to learn that. But in this country we can safely move people commercially from one point to another with absolutely minimal risk to their lives and their persons, as our records show.

I have spoken many times in the 12 years I have been in the Senate on the shortcomings of the Authority. As Senator Sanders said, I am the first to agree that it is grossly overregulated. In many ways it is archaic. That was why I moved that the Senate set up an inquiry into the management and the organisation of the Civil Aviation Authority and the Federal Airports Corporation. I believe there must be change in the way we regulate our affairs with respect to aviation. I believe it is costing us an enormous amount of money. But the system we have in place is safe even if it is ponderous. I am not an anarchist. Unlike Senator Sanders, I do not want to throw the baby out with the bath water. I want reasoned change in the Authority-a move to simplify and make structures and procedures more efficient-but I want to see safety maintained all the way. I want informed, experienced minds dealing with the regulatory problems in aviation in this country. I do not want any radically anarchistic ideas coming in and destroying a system which, even at its worst, is extremely safe, or it was until this Government moved into the regulatory function purely to protect the commercial interests of its mates in the airline industry.

The consequences of what the Government is doing in meddling with the Civil Aviation Authority are quite enormous. I am not exaggerating the devastating effect on the Australian community if two airliners collide, particularly over a capital city. I know it infuriates Senator Button when I say these sorts of things, but I have seen people killed. I have been at accident sites and I have had my friends killed in the air. Accidents do happen. The tragedy is that in nearly all cases they are preventable. What has happened under this Government is that prevention has been denied the Australian public. That is why Senator Chaney and the other speakers on this side of the Parliament are so concerned about what is happening. We have manifest evidence that the safety standards of this country have been abridged and compromised to a very dangerous degree.

I would like to say something about the questions which have been raised in the Senate and which have so infuriated the Australian Labor Party. They were real questions. Everyone asked whether something was true. It is our right to ask whether a certain event occurred. There is nothing wrong with that. But that is not the central point of our argument. The central point of our argument is not whether a French captain got confused and took a standard instrument departure to Shelley when he should have gone to Wollongong. The central point of our argument is that the failure that has occurred in the regulatory functions is putting the safety of the Australian public at risk and that is the consequence of the basest sort of political interference.

Let me remind the Senate that on Tuesday of this week the Guild of Air Pilots and Air Navigators spoke out on the safety compromises that are now taking place in Australia. The Guild would be totally unknown, I think, to the general public. It is a body that could claim to be the most prestigious body representing airmen in the world. It is a body that never seeks publicity and it never enters into anything which is at all controversial, political or party political. Yet on Tuesday of this week the Australian region of the Guild of Air Pilots and Air Navigators took the quite unprecedented step of speaking out about the dangers inherent in the present regulatory system pertaining to Australian air navigation.

Questions have been raised in the press about procedures and questions have been raised in the Parliament. The Government has denied that things have happened. Even worse, we have been told that because things have not happened there has not been any inquiry. In all of this, the Government's position has been supported by the Chief Executive Officer of the Authority, Mr Colin Freeland.

I want to deal for a little while with the Estimates committee procedures in this building on Tuesday night because they provide positive confirmation in the face of the Government assertions that somehow or other the document that Senator Chaney addressed might have been a little slanted. I want to deal with the transcript from Estimates Committee B in relation to a matter which I raised with Mr Thomas, who I believe is in the chamber this morning. He has been brought in as part of the panic move by the Government, to put the best interpretation possible on it. I apologise for taking up some time--

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't get personal. Leave the advisers alone. If you want to have a go at someone, have a go at us.
—Would you be quiet, Senator Collins.
—Order! Senator MacGibbon, please address the Chair. Senator Collins, interjections are disorderly.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I asked some questions about the issuing of certificates of validation for the French pilots who are flying for Airlines of Western Australia. Let me start at the beginning or it will confuse the simple minds of such people as Senator Collins. I asked initially about the issuing of licences such as aircraft maintenance engineering licences and pilots licences-whether they were issued within regions, Australia is divided into regions on a State basis, or whether it was done centrally. Mr Thomas replied:

SPEECH.PARA: Flight crew licences are still issued in the field offices in the regions . . .
I then said:
Now, the six French pilots flying for Airlines of Western Australia; where were their licences issued? In Canberra, or in Perth or in Melbourne?
Mr Thomas replied:
The pilots were issued certificates of validation. Those certificates, I understand, were issued from our Melbourne office.
The transcript continues:

TALK.START.PARA: —Why were they not issued from the Perth office?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Thomas-The pilots are flying for Ansett Airlines in Western Australia, and that airline is subject to training and checking control by Ansett in Melbourne, so the normal method of servicing that operator is through our Melbourne office.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are absolutely certain the validation was through Melbourne, not through Canberra?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Thomas-For what?

TALK.START.PARA: —The pilots.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Thomas showed great reluctance to answer. The transcript continues:
Mr Thomas-For the French pilots?

TALK.START.PARA: —For the French pilots flying for Airlines of Western Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Then there was a dramatic change:
Mr Thomas-Some of the certificates of validation were issued from Canberra.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why were they issued from Canberra?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Thomas-There was a public holiday in Melbourne on Thursday. They were issued late in the evening of the night before, and there were staff on duty there and not in our Melbourne office at the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —But some were issued from Melbourne, from what you have said and some from Canberra.

SPEECH.PARA: So it goes on. Further on, the transcript reads:

TALK.START.PARA: —Can you tell the Committee categorically that no-one in the CAA in the Victorian-Tasmanian region refused to issue those certificates?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Thomas-The certificates that were issued for aircraft captains were issued from Canberra and there was a difficulty with the Victorian-Tasmanian region.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was that difficulty?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Thomas-The Victorian-Tasmanian region field officers were concerned at the checks that were to be performed. They felt that additional checks would be wise.

TALK.START.PARA: —So you overrode them?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Thomas-Yes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Thomas-Because the document that had been provided to the airline that specified the requirements for the training of French pilots had been fully complied with.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did the Victorian group object, then?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Thomas-We are having discussions with them about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can understand an interpretation being placed upon this matter that the laid down procedures were not being followed.

SPEECH.PARA: So it goes on. Mr Thomas finally said:
The Ansett training manual is written to provide a training and checking organisation and to establish the flying standards within the airline. That manual was written some considerable time ago.

I would like to diverge for a moment and talk about operations manuals for airlines. They are absolute law. They have to be compiled before the Department will issue an air operators licence. I have never in my life heard that because a manual was old it was no longer valid. That manual is constantly updated and monitored, but any changes to it have to be made through the Civil Aviation Authority. The point of all this is that it relates very much to the letter by Mr Lewino that was ridiculed by Senator Button.
Let me turn to the letter of 2 October, the very recent past, from Captain Segan. He opens by saying:
By now you will be aware of concerns by CAA officers on the erosion of operational standards as a result of decisions made in the light of the extraordinary events of the last six weeks.
He goes on to say:
All officers were under considerable pressure from above to review standards and expedite approvals.
That is absolute proof that pressure had been placed on officers of the Department to bend standards. This statement was made by Captain Segan:

Our major error was to allow ourselves to be drawn into discussions with airline commercial management-a group who had no knowledge or interest in standards. Their approach was to attack our standards in an attempt to reduce training requirements, and they were successful. Their only negotiating point was the threat of ministerial action.

In other words, Bob Hawke and his minions would have dropped directly on the officers of the CAA. There is a lot of information about the way standards were waived and laid down procedures were not followed with respect to in command under supervision requirements for certification of new pilots. Senator Chaney has dealt with that matter.

I turn to the certificates of validation, which is a procedure by which foreign pilots can be authorised to fly within Australia. Senator Sanders ridiculed that when he said, `You can go to the United States and be issued with a licence to fly on the same day'. That is perfectly true; that has happened to me. I have held a United States Federal Aviation Administration licence that was issued on the spot, but it was only a private pilot's licence. It was for single-engined aeroplanes and it was for no commercial benefit. The granting of senior airline transport licences, which is what an airline pilot needs, is another matter entirely. Captain Segan said that the issuing of certificates of validation is meant for transitory cases, and is a device to allow foreign pilots limited private, display, ferry or instructional flying without requiring them to undergo full Australian licence examinations. He states-and this is the critical part:
It was never intended to permit full commercial operations at the highest category of licence by pilots who would normally be expected to have difficulty meeting our standards.

That is precisely what the French pilots flying with Airlines of Western Australia have been granted. I questioned Mr Thomas about the granting of the certificates during the Estimates Committee hearing. That is of relevance to the news in today's newspapers that the airlines are negotiating long term agreements for the lease of aircraft. Those aircraft will operate with foreign crews, under certificates of validation which are on the statute books to provide short term opportunities for pilots to fly in this country, not to run regular airline services. There was a great deal of discussion in the letter about Captain Smith. In his summary Captain Segan says:
The events of recent weeks have had a deleterious effect on our ability to set and administer standards for the airline industry. We have:
granted concessions, for purely political reasons . . .

Note the words `purely political reasons'. What does that mean? It means that Mr Hawke is looking after his mates again and leaning on the officers. Mr Lewino, the Assistant General Manager (Safety Regulations) in the Victorian-Tasmanian region and also the Assistant Regional Director-a very responsible person-wrote a very detailed letter. Anyone who is interested and has a background in aviation who reads Mr Lewino's letter will realise that it is utterly devastating for the Government and the Department. Senator Collins or Senator Button could not read this and understand its significance. To anyone with a technical background, it is utterly devastating. He says:
The current pilot dispute has seriously weakened the Ansett operational organisation, despite the fact that a number of more senior operational managers remained with the company.

One of the things that the Government has been able to suppress with its control of the National Media Liaison Service and the media is the fact that Captain Henry Theinssen, the most respected man in the whole of the Ansett organisation, its chief pilot, its manager of flight operations, resigned over three weeks ago because he told Sir Peter Abeles that he could no longer guarantee minimal safety standards within the Ansett organisation. That has not come out in the press but it is a fact, and it speaks volumes for what is going on in Ansett today. Later on Mr Lewino says:

A more serious consequence, which has manifested itself over the last week, is that operational managers are becoming fatigued. They are flying to the full limit of flight time and crew duty rules (in one case, over these limits) . . .

Companies have to have management pilots. There is a management role of seeing that manuals are updated, procedures are followed. It is a full time job. Ansett is driving these people beyond the human limits. It is making them be management pilots, doing the bookwork and the administration, and at the same time flying them to the limits in the air manning aircraft. As Mr Lewino said, over a three-day period from 23 to 25 September, Ansett requested three extensions of flight and crew duty times. That means they flew crews beyond the legal limit. Then there is the matter of Captain Colin Smith. I do not intend to devote any time to that because, while those matters are important, I do not have enough time to put them before the Senate today. There are more important matters to deal with.
On the third page of Mr Lewino's letter, he makes this statement:
In return, Mr Thomas advised that Captain Smith and Mr McMahon, Ansett's GM, had contacted him late the previous evening, via Minister Willis' office . . .

What is Minister Willis doing negotiating on regulatory standards and decisions that are made by the CAA? Why did Mr Willis have his sticky fingers in talking to Mr Thomas, Mr McMahon and Captain Smith? This Government set up the Civil Aviation Authority-primarily to get it off budget-as an independent statutory authority. Under the Act, the Minister cannot direct anything. The CAA is a discrete, independent body in Australia. Yet here we have a statement `via Mr Willis's office'. He was caught red-handed but the Government will say that there is no political pressure, no political gain involved in the debasement of standards at the present time.

The rest of Mr Lewino's letter deals very succinctly with the debasement of standards that is being carried on. Senator Chaney mentioned the sentence which said that Captain Smith sought approval to command an aircraft from the jump seat while he had two inexperienced first officers flying the aeroplane in the left-and the right-hand seat with a full load of unsuspecting, fare paying passengers. Mr Lewino, to his eternal credit, refused that request. On what we have before us, had the request been made at a higher level, we have to consider seriously that it might have been granted. And so it goes.

The matter that Senator Button raised about the licensing of British Aerospace check captains I view as an irrelevance. I do not think it is important at all. But the question raised by Senator Knowles yesterday on the operations outside controlled air space in Western Australia is mentioned. We have French pilots who do not understand English blundering around there. They can talk to air traffic controllers via the accepted International Civil Aviation Organisation vocabulary or the Australian air traffic controller vocabulary but where they get outside controlled air space there are no air traffic controllers and they are flying into airfields like the many that exist around Western Australia where there are no airfield control zones or anything like that. They have to get on the radio, advise their positions and their intentions. They have all sorts of people, non-professional pilots, coming back at them on the radio. They simply cannot understand it and they have to fly around with English speaking members on the flight deck to tell them what is happening. That is an appalling debasement of standards as we know it in this country.

One of the saddest parts about this morning's events is the fact that Mr Lewino and Mr Scaife, the Deputy Director for the Western Australian region, will clearly, as Senator Chaney said, have professional bags of cement put around their feet. I am advised that Mr Scaife has been brought by head office to Canberra today to be severely rebuked for his part in this matter and I have no doubt that Mr Lewino will be forced to pay a most severe price for having the integrity to fulfil his professional obligations.

The evidence before us raises the gravest questions about the professional integrity of people like Mr Freeland and Mr Rainbird. Mr Freeland has been on television defending the Government and saying there has not been the slightest debasement or erosion of aviation safety standards. Mr Rainbird was in this building on Tuesday night. He had every opportunity in response to questioning to come clean and inform the Senate. Instead, he chose the devious approach of remaining silent when leading questions were asked. What is going to happen? It is absolutely certain that we are going to have an accident in this country. We have tired pilots exceeding their tours of duty. We have emotional stress in the cockpits where we have strikebreakers flying in Australian aircraft. We have foreign pilots who do not speak the language. We have foreign pilots who do not understand what is happening. In these circumstances an accident is utterly unavoidable, and the tragedy is that it is all preventable if the Government would get its sticky fingers out of it. That is why the Senate finds Senator Button's actions so reprehensible and so deplorable, because the blood will be on Senator Button's hands.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, Senator MacGibbon's concluding remarks in the debate today are utterly reprehensible and he should be condemned for them. It is the kind of outrageous scaremongering that his leader yesterday was forced to attempt to defend him on. There is no excuse that can be offered for any senator, based on the misinformation that Senator MacGibbon particularly, on behalf of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots, has provided to the Senate, to make such an appalling statement in such a serious debate, and he stands condemned for it.

SPEECH.PARA: It might be a good idea to go over one or two of the furphies that Senator MacGibbon has placed before this House purporting to be fact. Senator MacGibbon, as I said yesterday, came into this Parliament last week waving a document around that he had been given by the Air Pilots Federation. It was a contract that he said proved that the companies were currently offering a 40 per cent boost to the current conditions under which pilots are employed in this country, 15 per cent more than they were asking for from the airlines.

Within 10 minutes of examining that document, which I compared with the Ansett contract that I had seen the day before, I discovered, of course, that Senator MacGibbon was absolutely up a tree, as he normally is. People in this House should not be mindless. If people are given documents they should at least take the trouble to examine them and simply not believe the nonsense that their leakers hand them at the same time as the document. When the document was examined it was discovered that the increase that it offered was in fact 6 per cent, not 40-3 per cent now and 3 per cent on 1 April next year, in exchange for a substantial increase in productivity and, I might add, some very important fundamental changes in the conditions under which the pilots were employed.

As I also said yesterday, the difficulty for Senator MacGibbon and the Opposition in continually going out on a limb for the airline pilots is that every time they stick their necks out on behalf of them, the Pilots Federation pulls the rug out from under them. I also said yesterday, and it is a fact, that having said for two weeks that these contracts offered a 40 per cent boost in their conditions, 15 per cent or more than they were asking for, and having had that line run in here by the Opposition on its behalf, the Federation said on Monday of this week that the contracts were unacceptable because `the contracts took them back to conditions that existed 30 years ago'. It was reported on the national news on Monday. The honourable senator cannot have it both ways. What they were referring to clearly by that statement was the removal of the seniority bidding system. That is exactly right.

Of course, I hope Senator Chaney is not suggesting that he can run a line about a 40 per cent increase and at the same time be silly enough to confine that to the pay section of the contract without looking at all the conditions of the contract. You have actually got to read a contract from the first page to the last where the signatures are. Senator MacGibbon obviously did not bother to do that.

But in terms of the number of other furphies that he has run, and his scaremongering, he really does need to be pulled up. It is about time his party leadership suggested that he should be a little less extreme in his statements. He put out a statement the other day about a 737 in which he said that the pilots had made serious errors and that there was the risk of a mid-air collision between two jet airliners over Sydney, over schools, et cetera. The fact in that case is, as I have now determined having looked at it yesterday, that the only mistakes that were made were made by the leakers to Senator MacGibbon, not by the pilots. The mistakes were made as a result of the total confusion among members of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots, who are continually leaking material to Senator MacGibbon to run his scaremongering tactics in here.

The airline pilots flying the 737 lodged a flight plan and had that flight plan approved. That flight plan involved flying the route, detailed in this House yesterday, from Sydney to Wollongong to Shelley to Corryong and to Melbourne. That was the flight plan they lodged; that was the route they flew on and they did not deviate from it. The fact is that the pilots of that aircraft made absolutely no errors at all. It is about time that Senator MacGibbon started being just a little bit more responsible in his headlong rush to peddle whatever nonsense the Federation hands him five minutes before he walks in here. He should check the facts first before he frightens the daylights out of the public. He is being totally irresponsible. I might add-it is worth referring to again-that, if people want any evidence of that, they can refer to the final remarks he made in this debate today before he sat down. His remarks were reprehensible and contemptible.

Let us also look at a few other little furphies that he ran in the debate today. He referred to Captain Theinyssen of Ansett Airlines of Australia, who he said had resigned. The information that I have just been given-I will check it out personally today-is that this officer retired because he had reached the eligible age for retirement. In fact, he was one of the older pilots in the company. He was eligible for retirement and he chose to exercise that right. He retired; he did not resign. I will check that out; I have just been given that information five minutes ago. We will be back in here tomorrow and we will see whether Senator MacGibbon's story stands up. I might add that Senator MacGibbon's track record so far is that he has done nothing but peddle rubbish in this chamber. On every occasion it has been knocked over 24 hours after he has delivered it.

Let us look at another piece of gross rubbish: Senator MacGibbon made the charge and the allegation here today that Minister Willis was involved directly in safety issues in consultations between Ansett and the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA). That is the charge he made, once again as a result of a leak from the Pilots Federation. The pilots led Senator MacGibbon up the garden path on the contracts; they led him up the garden path on the 737; and they have now led him up the garden path on this issue. What are the facts? The fact is that the technical staff of Ansett-I have spoken to the officer who was directly involved in this-wanted to contact Mr Thomas of the CAA, as they need to do from time to time, to discuss an issue late at night. They wanted to short-circuit the process of getting in touch with Mr Thomas to the quickest extent possible as it was late at night. They rang an officer who deals specifically with aviation matters in Mr Willis's office. The Minister was not involved personally at all. The reason they rang the Minister's office, a ministerial officer who deals full time with aviation matters, was to see whether he had a late night contact telephone number for Mr Thomas. That was the extent of the request that was made and that was the extent of the information that was provided. The officer concerned gave the Ansett technical people a telephone number. That was the end of it and, presumably, late on this particular night the Ansett technical people used the telephone number to contact Mr Thomas at his residence. On the basis of that, Senator MacGibbon came in here today and asserted-and the Hansard record will show it-that the Minister has directly involved himself in negotiations and discussions with the airlines on safety issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Terrible.

—That is right. Senator MacGibbon should withdraw it. He will not do so, of course.
