No doubt Senator MacGibbon will come in here tomorrow, stand up on his hind legs and deliver the latest piece of nonsense that the Federation has handed him. I suggest to Senator MacGibbon that on the three issues that I have raised so far, it is three strikes and he is out. If he is to retain any kind of credibility in this debate he ought to start vetting a little the information which he is handed by the Federation before he runs it in the chamber. He should also be a little careful that he does not conclude speeches by predicting airline disasters in this country-I am talking about blood on people's hands-based on such nonsense, because there is no excuse for it.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I intend to devote only five minutes to the substantive issue raised in these documents. I have had an opportunity to read the documents from cover to cover and to compare them-that is, the document authored by Mr Lewino and the document authored by Mr Segan. I have to say that the path of the leaking of these documents is known. It was from the Victorian-Tasmanian regional office of the CAA to the Air Pilots Federation and from the Air Pilots Federation to the media and the Opposition. That was the path of the leak and no doubt it led directly to Senator MacGibbon. Having watched him conferencing with his Leader in here he appears again to be the source of this leak. That is fair enough.

However, the document that Mr Lewino has authored appears to have been written for the purpose of being leaked. The reason I make this statement is that on comparing the references in the first document-that is, Lewino's document-with the same references and issues in the second document one sees a very marked difference between them. Mr Lewino has said some very nasty things in this document about a man called Smith-things which, if this document had been published abroad, are grossly defamatory. There is no question about that. By referring to that I am not impugning Mr Lewino's motives or character in any way. I do not know the man. Obviously the document has been written from serious concern, but it is a fairly sad document when one reads it. Most of the politics appear to be internal CAA politics between Central Office and its regional offices. That is not something that comes new to me. I am very familiar with the operations of the CAA because of my involvement, not as a pilot but as a frequent passenger and a person who knows a great many pilots socially and professionally.

I made the point yesterday that regrettably I have been involved in many incidents involving people turning at places where they should not have turned, which did not in fact happen in the case of the 737-Senator MacGibbon got it wrong-and involving maintenance failures. The point I made yesterday was that I was involved in those incidents over a period of years when there was no strike on by the Air Pilots Federation. I thought that point was made very succinctly in this debate this morning by Senator Sanders. I rarely agree with Senator Sanders, but this morning I was absolutely ad idem with him. I respect his knowledge in this area. He is quite right about the mass of regulations which control the CAA and the aviation industry in Australia.

I commend to all honourable senators, if they have never read it, a document authored by another Australian I admire greatly, and that is Dick Smith. I have enormous respect for Dick Smith. I commend to honourable senators his `hall of doom' document which he prepared some years ago on his frustrations in dealing with the Department. I mention that because I am pleased to see in these documents a reference to what is going on in the CAA, which is an attempt, in fact, to streamline its procedures-it has nothing to do with the airline pilots dispute-so that the end product of the procedures becomes the main point rather than the steps that are taken to achieve it. I suppose it is consistent with the program budgeting arrangements that we are bringing in; it is the same kind of approach. There are, of course, many officers in that monolithic organisation who no doubt are concerned and upset about the changes that are being made to streamline these procedures. But in going back to Mr Lewino's document, I just note a couple of things that stand out. There are references to people looking as though they `have aged years' and to people who have `a known history at deliberately breaking rules'. They are very personal references. They are all through this document. Take this one, for example:
I sent Mr Moss along as he developed over the years a proven ability to detect liars.

Now he does not actually say that Captain Smith is a liar, but the deliberate use of that kind of expression associated with complaints about Captain Smith gives the reader a deliberate impression that that is precisely what he is talking about and I am sure that that impression was meant to be deliberate.
He goes on to make another personal reference to Captain Smith. In fact, I will not read it out. That is the third. He then says again:
. . . Captain Smith lacked the maturity and judgement . . .

This is all the way through this document. The reason I point that out is that if we go to the second document, which refers to the same issue, we find there a far more measured and a far less personal approach-even though the complaint is there and the concern is there. I might add that its concern is delivered in just as effective a manner as the concern that these people had about Mr Smith, which leads me to a belief about this, knowing as I do the path of the leaks.
In fact, I might make one final reference to nail down the concern that I have about this first document. I noted this reference:

Mr Rainbird made reference on several occasions to the high workload I had been under since the pilots dispute started. I gained the impression he thought my judgement was distorted as a result of this. Also, that my differences with Captain Smith were known to everybody from the ``Prime Minister on down''.

There are deliberate references to politics, the Prime Minister, liars and so on. Such references pepper this first document and, as I said, it is a sad document. Obviously Mr Lewino did not like being crossed by the central office and overriden by the central office and he has got his rocks off in this document well and truly. He has really sat down and delivered a fair bit of bile. I am not saying that perhaps the circumstances that precipitated this brief were not in some way conducive to that, and perhaps the high workload that he is suffering under is conducive to that, but I think the document would have been far more effective if at least half of the personal references had been left out.

There is no doubt that this document, if it is given wide circulation, is going to do some considerable professional damage to one person. I, unfortunately, I guess like a number of members of this chamber, have had an unwelcome familiarity with the defamation laws of this country-on three occasions, on one side or the other. I know from my personal experience that one of the most serious defamations that you can make about any person, and rightly so, is a statement impugning that person's professional ability in terms of capacity to earn a living from a job. There is no doubt that-and I must say this with some regret-whereas the second document makes the same points very effectively about concerns about this particular person, the first document is in fact grossly defamatory. I regret that it is now out in wide circulation in the public domain because presumably Captain Smith will not have the opportunity of tracking down every single one of these copies to try to put his case, and I regret that.

I turn finally to the substantive issue involved in both of these documents-the procedures that were adopted in checking out the French captains on these aircraft that are concerned, the BAE146 aircraft which I have had the pleasure to fly on to Western Australia on a number of occasions. The reality is that Mr Lewino's main concern centred around the fact that British check pilots, that is, pilots employed by the company that manufactures these aircraft, did the final checks on the French pilots on these aircraft. The facts are that the Ansett Melbourne chief check pilot did go to Perth on 28 September and he did re-check the French pilots. This was in accord with what Mr Lewino himself wanted and I imagine it has allayed any concerns that Mr Lewino may have had. So, all of a sudden, where is the Opposition's censure motion issue? It has disappeared.

I make one further point about the comments made in these two documents: the pilots concerned who did the final checks are the BAe pilots themselves-they know more about this aircraft than any other pilots in the world. We can take this one step further. The pilots concerned, the check captains who carried out these final checks, were the same check captains who introduced this aircraft to Australia; they were the same check captains who in fact participated in writing the manual for the operations of these aircraft in Australian airspace. Not only were the final BAe check captains who were used more knowledgeable about the type of aircraft involved than any other pilot in the country-in fact, the Ansett captains who carried out the final checks were personnel that these people had trained-but they were the same pilots who had personally assisted in writing the operations manuals for the operations of these aircraft in Australian conditions. To suggest on that basis that the Australian public has been put at risk by these procedures is really drawing a very long bow indeed.

I believe-and I direct these remarks particularly to the Leader of the Opposition in the chamber who will sum up on behalf of the Opposition-that concerns about air safety are not just legitimate but should be canvassed in this Parliament. They are concerns that I personally am extremely sensitive to. Concerns about air safety, based on factual information, should in fact be the basis for censure motions. But I do say, Mr Acting Deputy President, that statements by Senator MacGibbon that there was an imminent risk of a mid-air collision of two aircraft over Sydney, that there will be an airline disaster in the near future in Australia and that blood will be on the hands of the Government as a result, are outrageous and are not justified at all by any of the evidence that has been delivered in this Parliament today.

I conclude in terms of nailing that down by referring to the final paragraph of the second leaked document tabled by Senator MacGibbon in which the officer concerned-even though, I must say, I think factually he is wrong in a number of the points he makes-talks about a breakdown of CAA communications which he says can, in fact, be repaired by fairly simple procedures, as he sees them, applied in the CAA to redress this issue. I would compare the measured, reasoned and careful response of this officer with the outrageous scaremongering, based presumably on the same issues, of Senator MacGibbon. I would ask the honourable senator for the sake of the Opposition's credibility and his own credibility in terms of his continued representation in this Parliament of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots, to cease and desist.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take up too much time of the Senate. However, in view of what is happening in this country, I believe that I should participate in this debate. Contrary to what Senator Collins just told us, I believe that incidents involving aircraft around Australia are on the increase. I am worried about the lack of concern that this Government has for airline safety. One of the offshoots of Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines not being able to operate is that the smaller airlines are experiencing heavy loadings. I use small airlines in Western Australia on a regular basis when travelling between my home town and the city. I would like to relate, in the short time available, certain incidents that have taken place. These pilots that I see regularly are getting tireder and tireder every day. They jump off a plane which has come from, say, Carnarvon, get straight into a different plane and go off somewhere else. Unfortunately, added to that workload for those experienced pilots, planes are being changed around and so are the pilots on those planes.

SPEECH.PARA: My experience has been that one goes to a corner in the terminal at Perth, where the pilot calls the passengers-there are seven or eight on each flight-and away they go together. One day, as I walked out I said to the pilot, `I have never seen you before', and he introduced himself. When we got outside to the plane I said, `I've never seen this plane before'. He said, `It's on charter but that's okay'. Mind you, there is nothing wrong with putting pilots and planes on a new run. Sooner or later a pilot has got to go to a new area. But normally on this particular airline-a small airline-and other airlines, there is an experienced pilot on that route and on the plane who is used to the approaches without air traffic controllers at the other end.

On this day, we got into the place but were short of seats at the back. The pilot asked me, `Would you like to sit off-side?'. I said, `Yes, I'd love to. I do so every time I can'. As we readied to leave the terminal he looked over his shoulder and called out to the people down the back, `Have you shut the door down there?'. My confidence was starting to take a bit of a dint. He had locked the door next to me. The pilot was on one side, I was on the other and the door was next to me. I am glad Senator Walsh has come into the chamber because he was in an incident over Bass Strait once. He evidently does not remember that incident but we will remind him later. We pulled out to the beginning of the main runway. When the pilot got his clearance, off we went. I was watching the instruments, and we were just ready to take off when my door flew right open. Fortunately, I had the harness fastened, as one is always supposed to do, and I did not fall out. The pilot was able to cut his engines and we had plenty of runway on which to pull up. He got on the two-way radio to the control tower making explanations. He then leaned over me and banged the door about five times, which showed the lack of maintenance on these aeroplanes, with all the loading that is taking place. Finally he got it shut and locked. Then he went back to the runway and stopped half way down it. I thought, `My God, if the same thing happens we will be off the end of the runway before he can pull up'.

Anyhow, we got going the second time and flew out to home, which takes an hour and a quarter. We were coming into a strange airport for the pilot. We came in in the middle of the airport. Normally the pilots come in at one end or the other, depending on which way the wind is blowing, then do a three-quarter turn to see that there are no stray stock or stray vehicles or the odd road grader on the runway-home being a country town-and whether it is safe to land. On his third time around the airstrip the pilot came down. He was flying the plane, of course, and I was not game to say anything, but he came down on the cross-strip.

TALK.START.PARA: —What?

—We came down on the cross-strip. That cross-strip has not been used for many years as far as I know, and is generally used for parking road making machines when they are maintaining the strip. When we landed I said to him--
—Have you had a ride in an ultra-light?

—No, not yet, and after this I do not expect to. After we landed I said to him, `The other pilots land on the other strip'. He said, `I just thought I would make it a bit different for you'. That was his answer. I will not delay the Senate for much longer on this matter, but there have been other incidents. I have flown a lot in small planes and these incidents are building up.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to pick up a couple of points that have been raised by other speakers. Senator Sanders-and I take him to be an experienced former military pilot-told us about pilots coming from overseas. He commented, and others have commented, about the incident in Sydney, when a plane took a wrong turn. There was no danger to safety. He said, `There was no other plane there'. I presume that the air traffic controllers checked the space after a plane took the wrong turn and not before it. The fact that there was no other plane there, I believe, was more good luck than good judgment. Of course, if there had been another plane there, as there could have been, there could have been an accident of the dimensions that Senator MacGibbon pointed out yesterday.

Mr Acting Deputy President, it is no different for a plane to take a wrong turn than it is for a bus, a motor car, or a heavy highway vehicle to do the same thing. In other words, contravening road laws can lead to accidents. Honourable senators may have read or heard about the buses in Adelaide last week. Obviously one bus was in the wrong place while the other bus was there legally, and there was an accident. Fortunately there was no loss of life. Senator Sanders mentioned that pilots coming from overseas take up to six months to be certified in Australia and I believe that that should continue. We have got the best safety record in the world and I believe that we should keep it that way.

I finish on the point that was made about scaremongering. Senator MacGibbon pointed out what could have happened over Sydney-I am not familiar with Wollongong-but he was accused by Senator Button and Senator Collins of scaremongering. Can you tell me, Mr Acting Deputy President, of any road safety program that does not use scaremongering tactics? Any material put out shows vivid pictures of accidents on the roads, I believe with some good results. When it comes to scaremongering to improve road safety and obeying the rules of the road, I believe it is best remembered when you scare yourself.

I can remember an incident in my own life over 20 years ago. It involved a railway line that has now been pulled out. I was breaking one of the unwritten rules of the road that you keep your eyes on the road. I was being inattentive. My mind and my eyes wandered. I came around a bend on a country road that I had come around a thousand times before and since, and I heard a railway engine whistling at me. I looked up and there were the lights going and the engine was just over there. I did not know whether to pull up or to try to get in front of it; so I went for the brakes and I stopped about one metre short. It took me about 10 minutes to have the courage to drive to the other side of the railway line and pull off the road. That improved my driving 1,000 per cent. That line was pulled out over 20 years ago. The incident occurred in 1968 when the standard gauge went through, but every time I drive past that crossing, which is an average of three times a week, my hair still stands on end, even though there is no longer a crossing. So I believe a bit of scaremongering on safety-in the air or on the road-does not go astray. If Senator MacGibbon did use scaremongering, I think it might have some good effect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened to this debate. In some ways Senator Panizza has made one of the finest contributions because he has really indicated what this debate is all about. It seems that the Opposition wants to use scaremongering tactics to make everybody more conscious of safety. That is in effect what he was saying. I have always understood that a censure motion is moved when a Minister or, indeed, a member, has been so derelict in his or her duty that the disapproval of his or her peers should be formally registered. That convention, I put it to the Senate today, has been corrupted. Having listened to the debate, it certainly has not been established that such behaviour has occurred on this occasion. It has not been suggested that a Minister has grossly and deliberately misled Parliament or has acted in such a gross and reckless way that the disapproval of his peers should be visited upon him.

SPEECH.PARA: Evidence has been given by way of anecdote, by way of leaked documents, and that evidence has been interpreted by different people in different ways. There is no doubt that air safety is a vital, essential and crucial issue for this Parliament to debate, but we have not been debating that today. What we have been debating is a motion of censure which seems to have lost its way amongst a series of anecdotes, a series of stories about people's personal experiences. I ask the mover of the motion to indicate how the anecdotes-and, as I say, Senator Panizza's contribution eloquently typified the style of the debate so far-can be related to a motion which should be one of the most solemn and serious procedures used in this chamber. It is clearly going to be defeated, and so it should be, because there is no substance to it. In addition, it should be defeated because it amounts to an abuse of process of the instruments of this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: -The case that was put by the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, was a very well presented case and it is a case for the Government to answer. It is clear that material that is now in the possession of the Leader of the Opposition is such that it gives rise to grave concerns about a most important question-in fact, probably the most important question affecting citizens of Australia; that is, their safety.
—But it is not a proper matter for a censure motion, is it?

—I am coming to that, Senator. As such, Senator Chaney is to be congratulated on raising the issue forcefully in this chamber, as are Senator MacGibbon, Senator Panizza and all of the other senators who have done so, either privately or publicly.

SPEECH.PARA: This issue of air safety is one on which Australia has prided itself. I do not have to canvass all of the questions that have been raised in this and other debates, but I will refer to the question of whether it is appropriate for the censure motion to be worded in the way that it is. I do not claim the right to be consulted about measures such as this. But had I been consulted on this particular measure I would have suggested that there was one further step that the Opposition could have taken prior to taking what I believe is a very serious measure, and that is moving a censure motion. Thus, it is my view that this is premature and it is not my intention at this stage to support the censure motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-The Senate has been debating a censure of the Leader of the Government, Senator Button, for:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . his failure to give proper consideration to concerns about air safety raised by the Opposition in light of grave concern at senior levels of the Civil Aviation Authority about current procedures and standards and condemns the Minister for his despicable allegation of improper motives and scaremongering in the Opposition's questioning of safety issues arising from the pilots' dispute.

The context of this debate is very clear from the contributions which have been made both by those who have supported the motion and by those who are opposed to it. The Minister again conceded in his contribution to the debate that the system is under stress. Of course we have been given clear notice by the airlines, and indeed by the Government, that that stress will continue. For quite a long time the Australian airlines system, according to the Government, according to the airlines, will be a stitching together of regular airline services with charter services, the use of the armed forces and the use of all sorts of fillers which will enable some proportion of the traffic to be transported. We have a system which is under stress and in the view of the Opposition-we have been saying this for a very long time, before these documents from the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) appeared in the public arena-it is important that the issue of safety be given careful consideration during this period of stress. Senator Panizza gave an anecdotal example of the difficulties which are being found by people using the air services. What we are seeking, and have been seeking, from the Government is the clearest possible assurance that all proper safety measures are being followed.

Until yesterday, the Opposition had been raising matters on the basis of reports, some public, some private, of incidents, difficulties, shortening of procedures and the telescoping of procedures which normally apply to the certification of pilots and aircraft. Of course the whole complexion of the debate is changed by the leaking of documents from the Civil Aviation Authority itself, documents not leaked directly to the Opposition, which show a high degree of disquiet and concern on the part of senior officers of that Authority. I indicated during the opening debate that I would seek leave of the Senate to table the documents to which I was referring, and Senator Button intervened by way of interjection to suggest that there were matters in the reports which should not be tabled. For that reason I withheld the seeking of leave to table the documents and I subsequently, at his request, conferred with the officials who are here advising him. They have specifically requested the deletion of one portion of the report of Mr Segan. I have deleted from the documents which I now seek to table, two paragraphs on page 4 of Mr Segan's report. I do that out of deference to the request of the Department and the Minister. I therefore seek leave to table the document in that slightly mutilated form.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Mr President, I am a little puzzled by the request, I must say, because there does seem to be considerable overlap in the two documents between what has been deleted and what is there, but I have conferred with you and I accept that there is a desire to prevent an injustice to any particular individual.

SPEECH.PARA: The complaint which we make about the Government and the complaint which we make about the Leader of the Government is the failure to give proper consideration to concerns which have been raised by the Opposition. The basis of that complaint is the blandness of the assurances we have received day after day from the Government when these matters have been raised. I think that the proper test to apply with respect to whether or not the Government has acted with responsibility is to ask whether the answers which have been given would have been given in the same form if the Ministers had known that this information would become public. I think that is a fair test. If we had had that additional information, would the assurances have been in the bland form in which they have been fed to us? I think the answer to that is clearly no.

We have had some very interesting debate in here about the politics and Byzantine regulations of the Civil Aviation Authority-the successor to the Department of Civil Aviation. It has a tradition which I think flowed from the people who came out of the Air Force in World War II. It is a very longstanding institution which has grown and has eventually wound up as the Civil Aviation Authority. I accept that it is probably extraordinarily bureaucratic and hidebound in a number of ways.

But this is not a debate about that. It is not a debate about the reform of those regulations because this is not the appropriate context in which to be forcing reforms to safety procedures. It is an entirely inappropriate context. If the Opposition were asked to join with the Government in an approach to ensuring aviation safety which is less bureaucratic and avoids some of the defects which have been identified by a number of people in the debate-Senator MacGibbon would, I suppose, be one of the Opposition senators most intimately concerned with these matters-it would, I am sure, agree that there is room for reform and change. But the serious allegation in these documents is that the changes are occurring not simply in a quest for efficiency but because there are particular stresses on the system which require to be met. What these documents suggest is a shaving of standards-using one of the expressions in the documents-under political and economic pressure. That is a matter which is of concern to the Opposition and I think it requires clear answer and consideration by the Government.

What we require of the Government, and what I think the Government should properly have done in its approach to this, is that it identify the fact that there are significant doubts within its own administration about the administration of safety standards during the current dispute and to ensure that there is a proper examination of that so the public can be fully reassured on this issue.

Senator Button tried to trivialise this matter, as he always does. It is one of his attempts to be disarming-by ignoring his responsibilities as a Minister and suggesting that the Opposition was simply complaining because he had been rude, which was quite true. I never used the expression that he had been rude. But if he wants to make a point of it, he was rude. He is always rude when he is crossed. That is part of his character. The point which is made in the motion is that he has made an allegation of improper motives on the part of the Opposition which is both unparliamentary and certainly unjustified on the facts in this case. Whenever we have raised the issue of safety, he has accused us of scaremongering. We say that clearly the safety issue is of vital importance and the time to be concerned about it is before an accident, not after.

There has been complaint about some of the things that have been said in the debate. Let me put it in my own words: the time for us to raise our concerns and the time for the Government to ensure those concerns are baseless, if that can be established, is before there is an incident which would lead us all to regret any inaction on the part of the Government, the Opposition or the Civil Aviation Authority.

This is not a debate about the internal politics of the CAA. It is a matter of supreme indifference to me, in the context of this debate about safety, whether there is an internal political problem within that organisation. What I say is that significant officials within the organisation suggest that politics have overridden proper safety considerations. Commercial considerations-the pressure to get planes in the air-have overriden proper safety considerations. These are very serious allegations. They supplement, complement, the anecdotal matters which have been brought to the Government's attention time and again by the Opposition over recent weeks.

If there are to be changes made in the way the Civil Aviation Authority is administered they should be made on their merits and not under the pressures of this dispute. We have an airline system which is probably now unique in the world. It will apparently remain in that unique condition for a long time. It is a cobbled-together airline system; it is made up of disparate and, it seems to me, often ill-fitting-together elements. It is causing people who are involved in the aviation industry to operate on a higher level of stress than people who are concerned with good management would think to be wise.

We have had a Government response on these issues which is contemptuous of any suggestion that the Government should be concerned. The leaking of these documents last night is ample evidence that the Government should have embarked on the strongest and strictest inquiry into the sorts of issues that the Opposition has been raising. The response has been totally inadequate and we believe this is an utterly appropriate occasion when, to use Senator Cooney's words, a Minister has been so derelict in his duty as to deserve the censure of his peers. I commend the motion to the Senate. I believe the Leader of the Government should be condemned for his cavalier attitude to this important matter.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Chaney's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 12.54 to 2 p.m.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that Senator Walsh will be leaving the chamber today somewhere about 20 minutes before the end of Question Time. He has to go to a medical appointment. Senator Walsh will be here for the bulk of Question Time; any questions that subsequently have to be directed to him could be directed to him tomorrow.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate in his capacity as Minister representing the Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Communications. What is the Government proposing to do to examine and satisfy itself and the public about the now public concerns of some senior employees of the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) about the shaving of standards which impact on safety because of political and commercial pressures applied during the pilots dispute?

—There have been no political pressures applied during the pilots dispute in relation to safety issues. The only political pressure which has been applied has been repeated requests from the Minister for Transport and Communications to the CAA to ensure that safety standards are maintained. In so far as the allegations which are contained in documents tabled or incorporated in Hansard by Senator Chaney this morning are concerned, those have already been the subject of discussions between the Minister and senior officers of CAA. In so far as there is any substance in those allegations, that has been refuted in comments made by me and other senators this morning.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question, Mr President. In the latter part of the Minister's answer he says that in so far as the allegations have any substance, that has been refuted. Is the Minister saying that the Government has already totally satisfied itself that there is no area for concern or no area which should cause concern, or is the process of examining those allegations still continuing? If the former is the case, what action is the Government going to take to enable the public to be assured that that is the situation?

—In the course of this morning's discussion I read into Hansard a comment from the senior officers of CAA relating to, for example, one of the allegations which the Opposition relied on as being an allegation of substance. That was the allegation that the examination by the BAe pilots of the French pilots in respect of the flying of the BAe aircraft in Western Australia was inadequate. I informed the Senate this morning that the chief check pilot of Ansett Airlines of Australia had, on 28 September, gone to Perth and rechecked those pilots himself. That was expressed as being of satisfaction to the particular officer who had made a complaint. That is what he had suggested-and that is what happened as a result. I cannot go through each and every allegation in that document and provide a precise answer as to what has happened in relation to those allegations, but some of them--
—Somebody will.
—Yes. Some of them are incorrect; some of them have been dealt with; and that process will continue.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article appearing in last week's Business Review Weekly magazine on the subject of pay packages for chief executives in Australia? Would it be true to say that the present capital gains tax is essential to ensuring that such packages bear a proper rate of income taxation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see the article and I must confess that I have not studied it in any great detail. But it is perfectly clear of course. It is clear, even if one did not refer to that particular article, that the answer to the second part of the question is yes; that is, it is essential that the present capital gains tax be retained to ensure that proper taxes are paid. The article refers to senior executives receiving a component of their remuneration which is dependent upon their staying with companies for a considerable period. I understand that five years is a common period. They are know colloquially, I believe, as `golden handcuff' arrangements. They often take the form of paper assets. Under the current capital gains tax legislation the real capital gains would be taxable.

ANSWER.PARA: If the capital gains tax is to be watered down, as some people have proposed, and specifically, if it is to be phased out at 20 per cent per year for each year in which an asset is held, at the end of five years, obviously, a capital gain on a particular asset becomes totally tax free. Were that change to be made to the capital gains tax legislation it would clearly provide a very big incentive for company executives to arrange their remuneration so that they received capital assets under golden handcuff arrangements, which they would then hold with the company for five years, thus completely evading the capital gains tax and, of course, evading the spirit of the income tax law. Traditional, ordinary taxpayers would have to pick up the bill for that.

The article also pointed to one chief executive in an Australian company who gets over two-thirds of his pay package in that unique way. I have spoken about this before-the 1c paid shares which the Chairman of Elders-IXL Ltd, Mr Elliott, picks up. According to that Business Review Weekly article, the recent one for six bonus issue of shares in Elders-IXL was worth nearly $6 1/2m to its chief executive. The dividend on those shares which he has already picked up is more than an extra $1 1/2m. The Opposition's long awaited tax and spending policy is due to be released next week. If that proposal to phase out entirely capital gains taxation for an asset which is held for five years is contained in the policy, we will know at whose instigation and for whose benefit that major rort of the taxation law will have been inserted in the Opposition's policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and Minister for Industrial Relations. Why is the Prime Minister refusing even to test the claimed willingness of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots (AFAP) to negotiate on pay, productivity and conditions? Does not the AFAP clearly still represent the vast majority of those former Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines pilots, whose early return to work is the only real option in order to obtain a resumption of normal and safe air services in this country? If so, does the Prime Minister's refusal even to consider talks between the airlines and the AFAP mean that Australians can look forward to many more months of makeshift and inadequate air services as well as the associated costs to the many small businesses involved in tourism and associated industries?
—Who wrote this for you-Sparkes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the interjection, I do not think Sparkes wrote it; I do not think John Howard did, either. Mr President, only someone who--
—Monkeys are supposed to laugh uproariously when you deliver a line like that. They are too dumb behind you even to laugh at you.
—I am not surprised, Senator.
—You are changing sides again.
—You change sides all the time.
—I am joining you for once, Senator.
—We can't get over there quickly enough.

—No, he means change sides in the Liberal Party, Senator. Only someone with no knowledge of this dispute would read much into the pilots' press statement of yesterday. From the outset of this dispute, the fundamental issue has been the Pilots Federation's insistence on negotiations outside the wage fixing principles.

ANSWER.PARA: The offer to which Senator Stone referred was communicated in yesterday's press release by Mr McCarthy. In that press release he went out of his way to say that the AFAP continued to refuse to negotiate within wage fixing guidelines. That press release also refers to basing the minimum 55 hours flight time, plus overtime, on the previous award. Of course it is the previous award which grew like topsy, largely under conservative governments, which is the real vice in this whole issue. That award allows for flight time to be credited without any actual flying taking place. So large wage increases are possible without productivity gains.

The Australian Financial Review this morning quotes the airlines as saying that this so-called new position represents in excess of a 30 per cent to 35 per cent claim. I believe the Pilots Federation put out a position it knew to be unacceptable in a further attempt to gain some media advantage. It appears it may have fooled the Opposition, although if this morning's newspapers are any guide it has not fooled anybody else. The matter is currently before the Commission and last Friday Mr Justice Maddern expressed a prima facie view that an award could be made based on the airlines' new pilot contracts. Whether the pilots become a party to that award will depend on whether they become a part of the award making process. If they do the Commission has indicated that it may make them a party to the award.

The Pilots Federation will be in a position to put its current position to the Full Bench, which should be convening shortly to consider a report from Commissioner Paine. Once an award is set up it will be up to individual pilots to decide whether they wish to be employed under these conditions. Naturally, Mr President, the Government hopes that a large number of these highly skilled workers, as the air pilots are, will elect to contribute, as they have in the past, to national prosperity and the solution of many of the problems to which Senator Stone adverts particularly-and I understand this-on behalf of constituents he has in north Queensland, for example. But the point has to be made, as it has been consistently made, that, given expected productivity improvements and pilot recruitment so far, there will be significantly fewer jobs for previous pilot employees. In any event, the airlines will rebuild with the clear objective of providing a better service more efficiently. The airlines have in the last few days put out public releases about their increasing capacity and about the schedules which they are now able to provide. I hope that continues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. The Minister's response might be construed as an answer to the first part of the question that I asked him but it is in no way a response to the other two parts of the question, which were: Does not the Federation clearly still represent the vast majority of those former Ansett and Australian Airlines pilots whose early return to work is the only real option? Surely the Government, if there is any reality left on that side of the chamber must recognise that. If so, does the refusal even to consider talks between the airlines and the Federation mean that Australians can look forward to many more months of the present shambles? Will the Minister venture an estimate of whether this dispute will be over by Christmas?

—No, Mr President, I am not in the business of making estimates, as Senator Stone has on numerous occasions about the future of the economy. But the question of whether the Federation represents the air pilots is not quite as simple as Senator Stone would have us believe. The Federation may well have the allegiance of many of the air pilots. The question is, however, whether the Federation is able to represent the air pilots in a representative capacity in negotiations with the airlines.
—That is childish logic. Respond to the question.

—It is logic. Senator Stone can describe it with any adjectives he likes. The question is whether it is able to represent the pilots in a representative capacity in negotiations with the airlines. That is the issue. In view of the fact that the Air Pilots Federation does not represent any employees of the airlines, has taken itself outside of the system and has refused to comply with the wage fixing guidelines, which are complied with by everybody else in this community, the airlines will not negotiate with the Pilots Federation.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and refer to press reports that Australia's Ambassador to Fiji, Mr Robert Cotton, was due to meet Fiji's interim Prime Minister yesterday. Did the meeting in fact take place? If so, was this meeting part of ongoing discussions Australia is having with the Fiji leadership? Were those discussions productive?

—I have been provided with notice of this question and the answer is that, yes, the Ambassador, Mr Cotton, did meet the Prime Minister of Fiji, Ratu Mara, on 4 October. The meeting was part of the ongoing dialogue which the Australian Government has maintained with the interim government of Fiji since January 1988. The meeting provided a valuable opportunity to clarify any misconceptions the Fiji Government may have had on the Australian Government's policy towards Fiji. It also enabled the Ambassador to discuss recent developments in Fiji, including Ratu Mara's decision to continue as Prime Minister after December 1989, and Major-General Rabuka's decision to return to the barracks.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: BROKEN HILL PROPRIETARY CO. LTD: INTERESTS IN SOUTH AFRICA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I preface my question by noting that the report on Australian activities in South Africa, the Code of Conduct for Australian companies with interests in the Republic of South Africa, the second report of the Administrator, May 1989, from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, lists on page 27 of schedule 3 the subsidiaries of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP). Is the Minister aware that BHP's business interests in South Africa, as listed in a letter dated 6 March 1989 from BHP's principal corporate solicitor, did not include Phoenix Mining Finance Co. Pty Ltd? Is the Minister further aware that the BHP financial statements published in August 1989 list that finance company as a wholly owned subsidiary in 1989 and in 1988 and, further, detail it as carrying on business activities in South Africa? Will the Minister request an explanation from BHP for this discrepancy and provide the answer to the Senate?

—The Code of Conduct for Australian companies with interests in the Republic of South Africa operates on a confidential basis. In spite of this the BHP group has consented to being named and having its interests in South Africa particularised in the two reports of the Code's Administrator. Senator Powell drew my attention to the fact that the BHP financial statements published in August 1989 list the Phoenix Mining Finance Co. Pty Ltd as a wholly owned subsidiary in 1988 and 1989, carrying on business activities in South Africa. Following Senator Powell's question, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade will write to the principal corporate solicitor of the BHP group seeking an explanation for the omission of that company in his letter to the Administrator of the Code of Conduct, Mr Bannerman, and further information so as to determine whether it falls within the terms of the Code.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and relates to the detention in South Korea of the Australian citizen and Uniting Church missionary, Dr Kim Jin-Yeop, under Korea's national security law. What action has the Australian Government taken to date regarding this case? Is the Australian Government willing to make strong representations for the release of Dr Kim?

—Dr Kim Jin-Yeop is an Australian citizen who was arrested on 4 September in Pusan, South Korea, allegedly for dealings with a North Korean agent in Korea. Dr Kim has been working at the Il Shin Presbyterian Hospital in Pusan since his arrival in South Korea in April 1989. Wider ramifications of this case have assumed a certain notoriety in Korea and have led to a number of arrests. The Government understands that relations with North Korea are a matter of great sensitivity in the south and has no wish to interfere in the Republic of Korea's judicial process. At the same time the Government has been concerned about the circumstances of Dr Kim's arrest and has made these concerns known both to Korean authorities in Seoul and to the Korean Embassy in Canberra. The present position is that Dr Kim is still under investigation for alleged breach of the Korean national security law and that a formal charge is still to be laid. The Australian Embassy in Seoul meanwhile has been closely monitoring Dr Kim's welfare. The Australian Consul has already paid a number of visits to Dr Kim and this has enabled him to be satisfied both as to Dr Kim's health and as to his immediate welfare. Dr Kim himself has volunteered that he has no complaints about his treatment in custody. I think honourable senators may be assured that the Government will continue its active interest in Dr Kim's situation. A senior departmental officer raised the matter with the Korean Ambassador again only last weekend. I hope that this answer today will further influence the Korean authorities to the concern we feel about this case.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Communications. It relates to the need for aircraft operating in Australia to be airworthy. Is it a fact, as claimed on morning television today, that Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) airworthiness surveyors do not have access to foreign aircraft brought in to provide services in Australia because of the pilots dispute? If that is the case, why is it so?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The provisions relating to airworthiness of foreign aircraft operating in Australia are prescribed by their own regulatory authorities in those foreign countries. For example, in the case of the two American airliners operating in Australia, the airworthiness regime is prescribed by the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) in the United States, which imposes obligations on the operator to carry out certain checks and maintenance procedures at regular intervals. The CAA is in constant touch with the FAA in the United States about the implementation of these procedures.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that the position of civil aircraft owned by foreign companies and flown by foreign pilots operating on Australian domestic routes is no different from all the international airlines which operate in Australia and which fly on a regular basis on routes in Australia. That is to say, the controlling authority is the controlling body of origin of the country from which the aircraft comes and those standards are international standards which are observed by the airlines concerned. There is no difference in respect of the airlines now operating on domestic routes here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. So that I can understand the Minister's answer, in the event that the dispute here is prolonged and the aircraft are used in this country over a prolonged time, is the Minister telling us that even under that circumstance while the aircraft operate here they will not be available for inspection by Australian airworthiness authorities?

—That is my understanding on the basis of reciprocal arrangements between airline regulatory authorities around the world and the standards, as I have said, are those prescribed by the country of origin and the obligations are those of the operator here in Australia as they would be in the country of origin.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BUSINESS SUPPORT FOR THE ARTS GROUP

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I refer to the recent formation of the Australian business support for the arts group. Is the Minister aware of expressed concern that the hoped for success of this fund raising venture to support the Australian arts industry may lead to a reduction in Government support for the arts and therefore not be a net benefit to the arts industry but simply a transfer of cost? Is this likely to occur or can the Minister assure the arts industry that this is not the Government's intention in its support for that group?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator McMullan would probably know, last night in Sydney I attended the launch of the Australian business support for the arts group. That question was certainly raised at that function by quite a number of people from various disciplines in the arts. The reality is that during the last few years there has been fairly substantial cost-cutting by government. The arts has been immunised, if you like, and quarantined from that, and in the end has survived and flourished at least in terms of government support. Having said that, it should also be noted that while support from the Government is over $60m per annum, it is estimated that last year business support for the arts right across Australia was somewhere around $30m, which would place funding from this source a long way behind that given in comparable countries through Europe and North America. Part of the charter of the group that was set up last night is to make sure that there is a proper data base so that business can know just where sponsorships might be needed. I would have thought that this information would be of great assistance to both business and the arts.

ANSWER.PARA: There is absolutely no intention on the part of the Government to reduce its commitment. But, rather, we need to make sure that the private sector brings up its commitment to match that of some comparable countries. And, sadly, I think even the people in the largely business audience last night would concede that, in very many instances, companies have avoided their responsibilities in this area. If we are to be able to better and more loudly proclaim those things which make us Australians, perhaps the private sector's time has come. But whenever its time comes, the Government's time will never go away and our commitment will remain.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate follows his answer to Senator Peter Baume about the entitlement of inspectors to examine foreign aircraft brought into Australia for domestic use. I remind the Minister that the core of his answer was that these aircraft are subject to international regulation, or regulation in the place of registration. I ask the Minister: Is it a fact that at least one aircraft which has been brought to Australia for use in the domestic service has been found to have significant defects? I remind the Minister that Mr Quinn, the aircraft inspector who was interviewed on television this morning, said that it had been found that the landing gear support of one aircraft, which is not flying, was cracked. I ask the Minister: Will he find out the facts relating to that aircraft and, in particular, whether, in terms of certification, it was an aircraft which domestic airlines were entitled to use on Australian routes because of its certification at its home base, which I understand to be either Liberia or Ireland? In light of the facts of that case, will he establish whether it would in fact be possible, therefore, for a deficient aircraft to be admitted to service in Australia simply on the basis of its foreign certification?
—In so far as the particular allegation made by Mr Quinn and repeated by Senator Chaney is concerned--
—It has been printed elsewhere. There is a Boeing 707 locked in the hangar.

—The honourable senator referred to it as having been made by Mr Quinn. In so far as that allegation is concerned, I will obtain an answer for Senator Chaney as soon as possible. I suppose the significant factor is that the aircraft, as I understand it, is not flying here anyway. But I might just make the point again, which I made in my answer to Senator Baume, that the airworthiness maintenance program is prescribed by the country of origin of the aircraft. Surveillance--
—That is ridiculous. Look, do you mean to say that an aircraft can come in here and fly for two or three years under a certificate from the USA and we don't check it? That is ridiculous.
—Order! Senator Lewis.

—No, I do not mean to say that at all, Senator. Let me complete the answer. Surveillance is the responsibility of the appropriate regulatory authority; compliance is the responsibility of the aircraft operator. For example, in the case of the American aircraft operating here, the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA)-the United States regulatory authority-sent both an airworthiness and an operations inspector to Australia three weeks ago to liaise with the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) to ensure that appropriate air worthiness arrangements were in place. It was satisfied about that, as I understand it. Subsequent to that the CAA has been in constant communication with both the FAA and other foreign regulatory authorities to ensure that safety is not compromised. I will seek to obtain an answer as to the particular circumstance which Senator Chaney addresses to me.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note that part of the Minister's answer where he said that compliance is the responsibility of the operator. In getting the further reply which he has promised, will he also advise the Senate whether it is the situation that if an airline operator in Australia is in any way deficient in ensuring compliance with Australian standards, there is no independent check by the Civil Aviation Authority as far as the standards of the aircraft are concerned?
—Yes.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Can the Minister say whether the Government intends to postpone the commencement of its corporations legislation to allow time for the High Court of Australia to deal with any constitutional challenges by the States?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is very anxious to bring the national corporations legislation passed by this Parliament into force at the earliest possible date. Most parts of the Australian Securities Commission Act commenced on 1 July this year. Honourable senators would know that Mr Tony Hartnell has been appointed Chairman. This will enable the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) to set up the necessary infrastructure to properly administer the Corporations Act. Relevant parts of that Act will not be proclaimed, of course, until the Government is informed that the ASC is ready to administer the legislation.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators would know that the States of New South Wales, South Australia, Queensland and Western Australia issued writs challenging the constitutional validity of the legislation in the High Court. Directions hearings have been held with a view to narrowing the issues for determination by the Court. Queensland announced on 3 October that it was withdrawing from the High Court challenge, leaving New South Wales, South Australia and Western Australia to argue the case.

The parties have settled on two questions for determination by the Court. The first asks whether the Commonwealth's attempt to legislate for the incorporation of companies, including shelf companies, is valid. The second questions the validity of sections 112 and 113 of the Corporations Act which prohibit outsize partnerships and the incorporation of trading corporations under State or Territory law instead of the Corporations Act. The Commonwealth has agreed that if the High Court rules against it on the first question it will not proclaim those parts of the Corporations Act that relate to incorporation, internal management and winding up.

To answer the question more directly, the main factor which will determine the date of proclamation of the legislation will be the readiness of the ASC to administer it. Mr Hartnell has indicated that he anticipates the starting date for full operation of the ASC will be 1 July 1990.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Button in his capacity as Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and also as Minister representing the Ministers for Transport and Communications and Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to the decision by the Australia to Europe Shipping Conference to impose a $200 surcharge on every container shipped between Europe and Sydney. Is it a fact that this charge has been imposed because of the persistent and outrageous delays to shipping, averaging almost two days per vessel, caused by the gross inefficiency of the Sydney waterfront? Is the Minister aware that shippers put this cost at about $30,000 per day per ship and that this year such losses already amount to about $18m-that is, for the shippers; let alone the trucks that are queued there all day and night? Is it a fact that Sydney now joins Genoa as one of the few world ports to have a congestion surcharge, an honour usually reserved for Third World countries? Has the Government considered yet the report of the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority on the so-called in-principle agreement reached on changes to the waterfront? If so, what has the Government decided? If not, will the Government have the courage to reject this agreement which amounts to nothing more than a recipe for further stagnation at the expense of the taxpayers?
—I do not know why Senator Lewis bothers to ask questions when he begs every question that he asks.
—I am seeking information.

—No, Senator Lewis is not looking for some information, he is making a little speech. I understand that on 4 October shipping lines in the Australia to Europe Shipping Conference announced the imposition of a congestion surcharge to be introduced on 19 October on cargo moved through Sydney to and from Europe.

—Senator Lewis asked me whether that was correct; I am telling him. By the end of his next period in opposition he will learn how to ask a question. While the imposition of a congestion surcharge is a matter for the commercial judgment of shipping lines, the Government is, of course, disappointed that they found it necessary to exercise their commercial judgment to introduce a surcharge which will increase costs for Australia's exporters. In so far as the second part of the question is concerned, the Minister for Transport and Communications has received a report on the reform of Australia's waterfront. That will be examined by the Government and decisions made about it, I understand, next week. That will ensure that an appropriate environment is put in place for the long term benefit of all users of Australian ports and the waterfront industry itself. The Government will continue to play a positive role in that process after a decision is made next week.

—I am not sure whether this question should be asked of the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories or the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. I will direct it to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, although the question arises out of the conference on the control of chemical weapons held recently in Canberra. Is the Minister aware that, as long ago as 1969, 80 countries voted to include tear gas agents among chemical weapons banned under the Geneva protocol? Is the Minister aware that mace, the active ingredient of which is chloroacetophenone, or CN, was used last week at Nurrungar against civilian protesters? Is the Minister further aware than CN is an acutely toxic agent which has caused severe and permanent eye damage, acute as well as allergic dermatitis and death, and is probably mutagenic and carcinogenic? Was the agent used to propel the CN at Nurrungar a chlorofluorocarbon (CFC)? Will the Minister for Community Services and Health undertake to see that CN, CS gas, as well as other tear gas agents, are banned from use in Australia because they pose an unacceptable risk to the health of those against whom these agents are used?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can confirm the first part of the question. In 1969 in the United Nations General Assembly a resolution on chemical and biological weapons was introduced, calling for accessions to the protocol. It called for `a clear affirmation' that it covered the use in war of all chemical and biological weapons including tear gas and other harassing agents. The resolution was adopted by a vote of 80 to three. Australia, the United States and Portugal were the three that voted against it and there were 36 abstentions. It is now generally accepted internationally, however, that riot control agents are not chemical weapons. The Australian Government's view is that the widespread availability and use of these agents and their relative lack of toxicity and persistence make it impossible to include these agents within the scope of a convention which is to attract widespread adherence and is to be effectively verifiable.

ANSWER.PARA: Turning to the other parts of the question: I understand that at the recent protest at the Nurrungar base the irritant agent mace was used by a policeman against a protester. I think it is important to say that it was not used by any Commonwealth officer or any member of the Commonwealth Defence Force. My understanding is that it may have been used by an officer of the South Australian police force. I am unable to verify that, so I cannot state it as an unequivocal fact. The allegation is that that was the case, but I have not been able to confirm it with the South Australian police force. The consideration of the effects of this agent is outside the ambit of the Department, so I cannot give Senator Coulter a dissertation on the effects. However, I am able to provide some general information on the toxicology of the active ingredient of mace, which is chloroacetophenone.

I do not know, in giving Senator Coulter this information, whether the mace used was of a heavy, medium or low concentration. This is just general information and may not apply to the specific mace that was used in the circumstances. CN, also known as mace gas or as a tear gas, is a chemical substance, chloroacetophenone, as I said, and is used as a riot control agent because of its property of causing lachrymation, otherwise known as crying or tears flowing, to persons exposed to it. Eye exposure to CN will result in a burning sensation in the eyes, pain and crying. These effects can last up to 30 minutes or longer. Redness and swelling may continue for one or two days after exposure to CN. Permanent and severe eye injury is possible but is unlikely unless the person has been exposed to very high concentrations of CN. I am unable to say at this stage whether a CFC was used to propel the CN at Nurrungar. In the last question Senator Coulter makes a categorical statement that mace has unacceptable risks to health. I assume he believes that it has mutagenic or carcinogenic properties. I have to say from a health point of view that I do not know whether that is true. But I have asked the relevant authority to investigate that and give me a report, and I will reply to that aspect of the question in due course. I make the point that it is an assertion by Senator Coulter that is not at this stage proven.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister also confirm that as an alkalising agent one would expect these agents, CN and CS, to be mutagens and carcinogens and that because they have been used principally as riot control agents they have escaped proper toxicological tests? Will he undertake the necessary investigations so that we can be more properly informed? Is he aware that in the literature one can find at least six cases of death resulting from exposure to tear gas?

—I said that the mutagenic or carcinogenic effect of tear gas was an assertion by Senator Coulter which I have not yet been able to establish as being true. I said as well that I would refer that issue to the proper authorities for a report and give it to Senator Coulter in due course. In answering his supplementary question, I do not accept necessarily that his assertion is now true, when five minutes ago I did not accept it as being true, but I will acquire the report and give it to him in due course.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 September Senator Calvert asked me a question without notice about the impact of a recent Budget measure on Brisbane City Council and on local government generally throughout Australia. At present the collection of remittances is on a monthly basis. This is in effect a concession by the Federal Government because employers deduct pay as you earn tax on a more regular basis, usually weekly or fortnightly. The measure reduces the concession and is intended to get a more timely payment of revenue due to the Federal Government. This will enable the Government to make estimated public debt interest savings of $20m in 1989-90, and $70m in 1990-91 and in subsequent years.

ANSWER.PARA: In respect of the taxation affairs of the Brisbane City Council, I am advised that the Council estimates that its forgone revenue from the change in PAYE remittances dates will be about $180,000 in a full year, not the $360,000 suggested by Senator Calvert. The Australian Taxation Office estimates that the measure will affect fewer than 20 local governments throughout Australia at a cost of about $400,000 in 1989-90 and $1.5m per annum in following years. While there is no correlation between this initiative and untied financial assistance grants to local government, Brisbane City Council's grant is expected to increase this year in excess of $344,000 to over $16.5m.

The Federal Government will provide an estimated $675m to local government in 1989-90. Together with the initiative introduced last year, whereby local government can rate Telecom Australia and Australia Post, almost $50m extra is being made available to local government this year compared with the possible $400,000 in forgone revenue from pay as you earn remittances.

—In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following two reports of the Auditor-General: report of the independent auditor on an efficiency audit of the Australian Audit Office; final report of special audit: the Aboriginal Development Corporation and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 298th report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts entitled Report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts' Activities 1988-89. I seek leave to move a motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

Report 298 is the annual report of the Committee and will give members some indication of the wide range of subjects covered by the Committee in its work. Time precludes a comprehensive discussion of the report but I would like to highlight one particular initiative which is the centrepiece of the work of the Committee.

The Committee presented its report 296 on the reform of the Australian Audit Office (AAO) to the Parliament on 6 April this year. The report was entitled Ally of the People and Parliament: Reform of the Australian Audit Office. The report was the result of the first comprehensive inquiry into the work of the Audit Office in its 88 years of existence.

The Committee found that the Audit Office did not have the resources and independence necessary to perform its functions under the Audit Act to the satisfaction of the Parliament, nor had the Audit Office kept pace with reforms in the audit function in other jurisdictions.
The Committee made 78 recommendations, the most crucial of which were:
legislation be introduced to establish the AAO as a statutory authority, and to permit the Auditor-General to determine the terms and conditions of employment of AAO staff;
repeal of the Audit Act 1901 and its replacement by a new Audit Act and a new Financial Administration Act;
a parliamentary committee be established to advise the Auditor-General on Parliament's audit priorities and to consider the AAO's finances in detail; and

the provision of additional resources specifically to allow for more efficiency audits so that in five years time 50 per cent of the AAO's resources will be spent on efficiency audits as distinct from 6 per cent now.

This report has been fully supported by the Auditor-General who presented his response to the report to the Parliament on 7 September. There was only one recommendation to which the Auditor-General gave qualified support. The rest were given full support. The Auditor-General has urged the Government to act to give effect to the historic reforms recommended by the Committee. Indeed, this has been the response of Auditors-General around the country and of the editorial writers of almost all major Australian newspapers.

The Committee remains totally committed to the report and believes it is imperative that the Government accept the recommendations as the Committee believes they provide the blueprint for both greater accountability and efficiency in government.

The report contains detailed summaries of the reports presented to the Parliament in the 1988-89 financial year as well as a summary of activity in current inquiries. The Committee notes that a Bill on therapeutic goods was introduced into the Parliament yesterday and that the resources for the Antarctic Division have been increased in line with Committee recommendations.

In conclusion I want to thank all members of the Committee and members of the secretariat for their support during the year. I commend the report to the Senate. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 299th report of the Joint Committee on Public Accounts entitled Compliance with Guidelines for the Preparation of Departmental Annual Reports and seek leave to move a motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I would like to speak briefly to the report. Compliance with mandatory reporting requirements for departmental annual reports to Parliament should be a straightforward and administrative matter. Non-compliance with such requirements, however, is a threat to our concept of democracy. The Public Accounts A Committee produced the report I am tabling today because we found a substantial level of non-compliance. The reporting requirements for annual reports by the secretaries of Commonwealth departments are set down in guidelines approved by the Public Accounts Committee (PAC) and presented in the Parliament by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). This procedure and the requirement that reports be in accordance with the guidelines is provided for in section 25 of the Public Service Act 1922.

Last year, in its report No. 291, the Public Accounts Committee foreshadowed that it would review annual reports of departments for compliance with relevant guidelines. This inquiry followed on from the Committee's report No. 262, in which the Committee considered the draft which became the current guidelines for the preparation of departmental annual reports. Originally, the review was intended merely to confirm that secretaries of Commonwealth government departments were complying with the requirement that they include certain information in their 1987-88 annual reports to Parliament. Compliance by secretaries was, after all, required by the Public Service Act.

During the inquiry the Committee was most concerned at the level of non-compliance with the guidelines. This concern was heightened as the attention of each Secretary personally had been drawn to the guidelines by the Committee by way of letter. Further, the Committee had put on notice its intention to review compliance with the requirements of the guidelines. What more need we have done to achieve compliance? Even if departmental secretaries themselves believed that the accountability requirements were excessive-and this is not what they have told us-surely they can see that if departments do not report in the manner required by the Parliament the recent reforms in public sector management will be put at risk.

Management for results and devolution include a trade-off of more autonomy and control for more accountability. In this regard, we were pleased to hear that some departments were taking steps to ensure that problems of non-compliance will not be an attribute of the 1988-89 reports. The Committee encourages all parties concerned with annual reports to take an active interest in ensuring that they are useful documents. If scope to improve significantly the guidelines is identified, this should be drawn to the attention of the relevant bodies, the first being the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. For our part, the Public Accounts Committee has commenced a review of the guidelines which is intended to assist the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet in redrafting those guidelines by giving a parliamentary perspective. The review will also give the Committee an opportunity to consider its preferences for the guidelines prior to being required to consider the draft guidelines for approval under the Public Service Act.

The Committee awaits the 1988-89 reports with interest as they will no doubt comply with the requirements of that Act and thus provide improved information on the operations of Commonwealth departments. Also, the initiative and skill of departments should be reflected in the way they present the required information in a manner which is concise and accessible to the reader. In a public hearing it was said that the Prime Minister's guidelines seemed to have been totally regarded with contempt by much of the Public Service. Very simply, I hope annual reports will never again lead any of us to that conclusion and that this inquiry has contributed to this.

In closing, I would like to thank my fellow Committee members, the various departmental secretaries and their staff and the staff of the PAC secretariat for their efforts in producing this report. This is not an inquiry which the Public Accounts Committee wished to conduct and, in fact, the Committee went to great lengths to avoid it. It has been an inquiry which has involved some considerable embarrassment to some Commonwealth public sector managers and I am confident that important lessons have been learned from it. Above all else, it has been a forthright assertion of the supremacy of Parliament-a concept fundamental to Australian parliamentary democracy. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
