TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise two matters, one of which relates to the subject matter of Senator Patterson's question about the outrageous behaviour of the honourable member for Canberra, Mrs Kelly. In the circumstances, I believe that it demands explanations from the highest level, in particular from Mr Willis as the senior Minister in that portfolio.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the so-called important message to telephone customers from Ros Kelly, I would like to know whether this decision to have the Minister's name attached to a Telecom Australia document-in other words, a blatant electioneering stunt-was considered by the Telecom Board; whether the matter was authorised by the Board; and in what circumstances Telecom agreed to such a shoddy piece of electioneering activity. I would also like to know the number of letters distributed, and for what reason it was felt necessary to circulate consumers in the Canberra and Queanbeyan regions, given that there has been extensive telephone advertising on this very matter in recent times, and only those who do not read newspapers would fail to be aware that telephone numbers are about to be changed. I ask whether this practice is about to be followed in other areas, and indeed whether it has been followed in the past. On this occasion was it distributed on an electorate basis, and if so did it include the electorate of Fraser? I would also like to know the cost of the mail-out.

I invite the honourable member for Canberra, Mrs Kelly, to indicate whether the recently installed folding machine that she now has in her office, which is capable of posting 40,000 letters in one go, was obtained from the Department of Administrative Services, or through the Department of Telecommunications and Aviation Support. The machine was no doubt installed for much higher ministerial purposes but no doubt has been used for quite a deal of electioneering material in recent times including-so I am informed-an 80,000 mail-out on the instructions of the Treasurer, Mr Keating. I ask whether that machine was used for this particular purpose.

I regard this behaviour as symptomatic of the approach that has been taken by the Government. It is yet another one of its dirty tricks in the run-up to the next Federal election. It is all part of its continuing campaign to transfer the burden of seeking re-election to the Government and to the taxpayer rather than to the party machine. There can be no justification at all for a Minister seeking to intrude into what is essentially a machinery matter for Telecom. Telecom no doubt writes to its consumers on a regular basis. Our accounts are sent to us pretty regularly. There is no reason why that account could not contain information of this nature. Indeed, the letter states that it is a fairly minor change, or words to that effect. The letter states:
The new arrangements are really quite simple- . . . just prefix your current telephone number with a `2'.

It would not take much effort to include that with the next bill that goes out. But what has happened is that the Telecom Customer Services Manager has allowed his signature-no doubt after ministerial heavying-to appear on the letter with the Minister's signature. I regard that as a total abuse of the role of the Minister and a compromising of a supposedly independent government business authority.

I also wish to raise another matter in the same general area. It relates to a press release put out by Mr Willis and a subsequent report in this morning's Australian Financial Review of the new members of Austel, the independent regulatory body for the telecommunications industry. A report by Anne Davies says:
Ms Johanna Plante, the national manager of Infonet, and Mr Alex Arena, a senior manager at Australia Post . . . have been appointed full-time members.
Anne Davies goes on to say:
Notably, the Government has decided not to appoint anyone from Telecom, a move which would have alarmed the private sector.

She is quite right about that. But the fact is that it is not at all clear where that particular piece of disinformation came from. I strongly suspect that it was fed to her by Telecom, if not by the Minister's office. In any event, I regard it as a serious matter in view of the information provided to me which indicates that Ms Plante, far from being a private sector person by way of background, has had a long history of employment with Telecom. Mr Willis's press release merely says this:
Mr Willis said that in selecting the remaining AUSTEL members he was conscious of the need to appoint members who would contribute superior technical and economic expertise.

``Ms Plante, who is currently the National Manager of INFONET, has an engineering background and has worked in senior management and as a communications consultant in private industry,'' Mr Willis said.
``She has also established two State branches of the Australian Telecommunications Users' Group.

I am not suggesting that Ms Plante is not academically or technically qualified but what I am complaining about is that if it is a fact that she has had a long and extensive history of employment with Telecom, other than a couple of years in the private sector with Coopers and Lybrand, she should have been described in Mr Willis's press release as someone with an extensive Telecom background. Indeed, the organisation of which she is currently the national manager is one in which Telecom has a 5 per cent interest, one that is very close to Telecom. It is quite possible that Ms Plante has only been in that position on secondment from her permanent employment with Telecom. If that is the case, I regard Mr Willis's press release as thoroughly deceptive and misleading in its nature and it should be investigated by the appropriate body. I hope that Austel will clarify the position.

The release is carefully worded to avoid any mention of any Telecom background. It is hard to believe that that can have been accidental. It requires an explanation. These are serious allegations. Whilst the release is at pains to stress the technical and economic expertise, it does not, of course, highlight the fact that we will now have Austel, an independent regulator, consisting of three public servants and two academics-no private people. Yet the way in which the description is made is designed to suggest an extensive private sector background for at least one of the recent appointees.

I welcome, in particular, the appointment of Mr Arena and Professor Fels, both of whom are known to me. I regard them as very capable and competent people. I do not know Professor Round but I am sure that his qualifications are similarly appropriate. Ms Plante is unknown to me and I have no personal quarrel with her. But if she does have an extensive Telecom background that fact should have been put up front; it should have been made known to the Minister, as I am sure it was. It certainly, therefore, should have resulted in a mention in the press release. Whoever is responsible for advising Anne Davies that the Government had decided not to appoint anyone from Telecom was gilding the lily to a considerable extent and I regard it as very unsatisfactory that the Government should seek to disguise the true nature of appointments in this shabby way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address myself to the first issue that is of concern to me, and that is evidence that has flowed from the Estimates Committee D hearing of 28 September. Estimates Committee D covers the portfolio of sport which is, of course, Senator Richardson's. I took the opportunity while at that Estimates Committee hearing to ask the Australian Institute of Sport (AIS)-I asked Mr Crosswhite, the Acting Director, in particular-what steps it was taking in respect of the findings, the conclusions and the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts which had inquired into the use of drugs in sport and, in particular, into the use and misuse of drugs at the Australian Institute of Sport.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to say that Mr Crosswhite gave very disturbing evidence. He provided the Committee with the findings which had been arrived at by the Chairman and the Deputy Chairman of the Board. By any measure, if those findings are accepted by the Government it means that the Government has done absolutely nothing about the problems at the Australian Institute of Sport. That would be a great tragedy because it is a fine institution with some very dedicated and committed young athletes who have given of their time, their energy, their effort and much of their life in pursuit of their endeavours and excellence. Their reputations are being tainted and touched by the incompetence of certain administrators at the Institute of Sport and by the corruption of some coaches.

The recommendations that I am concerned about primarily relate to a Mr Wardle, a weight lifting coach assistant at the Institute; Mr Peter Bowman, one of the senior administrators now at the Institute; and an athlete there, Miss Jane Flemming. I asked Mr Crosswhite to tell me what was being done about the recommendations. Let me just touch upon Jane Flemming. I do not have the answers; I do not have the panacea; I am not seeking to judge what steps ought to be taken in terms of discipline. But Jane Flemming has been put up by the Institute, encouraged to come before our Committee and give evidence, by Mr Peter Bowman. She is used, and quite properly so, as the healthy, young, clear skinned PR girl for the Institute who says what a wonderful institution it is, and quite rightly so. But she unwisely and foolishly said that no drugs were used there. I am quite certain she was using somebody else's words and not speaking from her own knowledge.

Sadly, Miss Jane Flemming in 1986 in Belfast, at a meeting which led up to the Commonwealth Games in Edinburgh, got caught up in seeking to corrupt the drug testing system, which goes to the heart of cheating. It goes to the heart of fairness and decency in ensuring that the right people win. A Miss Susan Howland had been successful in her event and was called upon, randomly I understand, to submit herself to a drug test and to provide a urine sample. A Mr Plant, an official of the Amateur Athletics Union of Australia, for reasons best known to him, concluded that Susan Howland, on having her own urine tested, would be found to be positive. In other words, she would have been cheating. So Mr Plant asked Miss Jane Flemming to provide a urine sample.

This incident was totally unrelated to Miss Flemming except that she was at the Games, at that time a student of the Institute of Sport on a full scholarship. He asked her whether she would provide a urine sample, and that she did. She gave it to Mr Plant to replace the urine sample of Miss Susan Howland for the purpose and with the intention of ensuring the test was negative, because it was assumed by Mr Plant, as I say, that Miss Howland would be found positive. In other words, Miss Jane Flemming conspired with and was party to a test to cheat the testing system. As it turns out, according to Mr Plant, for reasons again best known to himself, he disposed of the sample. Miss Howland's urine was used. She tested negative and her medal was presented to her. Miss Howland has since given evidence-and I have no reason to believe that it is not accurate-that she knew nothing of these circumstances, she knew nothing about any suggestion that she would test positive or any suggestion that another urine sample would replace hers.

That is sad when one contrasts Miss Flemming's personal conduct with her presentation of all the virtues and goodness of athletes at the Institute of Sport. Miss Flemming came along originally to give evidence-to tell us that all these unreasonable, unfair stories we had heard about the Institute were not right. She had been assisted in the drawing up of her written evidence by Peter Bowman from the Institute, who contacted the Committee and encouraged us to take oral evidence from her, which we of course did. We recommended that some disciplinary action be taken against Miss Flemming because she was a full time student at the Institute of Sport and certain standards are expected of scholarship holders, not the least being that they will conduct themselves in a sportsmanlike fashion, they will not cheat and they will uphold the ideals with which the Institute wishes to be associated.

The Board, under the auspices of the Chairman and the Deputy Chairman, looked at our recommendations and allegedly read the transcript of the evidence. Their action was to send a letter to Jane Flemming informing her that the Board of the Australian Sports Commission (ASC) strongly disapproved of her participation in urine substitution. She has not been disciplined, chastised or criticised; it has simply been pointed out to her in writing that the Board disapproved of her participation in urine substitution. If that is likely to discourage other athletes, students and scholarship holders from doing the same thing, I would be absolutely staggered because normally the rules are that scholarship holders at the Institute of Sport who get caught cheating get kicked out. I am not calling for that-I am not calling for anything-but I would have thought that prima facie in this environment the Board would have at least taken some modest steps; in the interests of sport, the coaches and the athletes at the Institute, it would have been seen at least to have taken some steps. Yet it did absolutely nothing. It did say, `All AIS athletes and coaches be informed that participation in urine substitution now constitutes a breach of the ASC-AIS drug policy'-as it is now a sin to substitute urine, a sin to cheat, do I take it that it was not a sin prior to this ex cathedra dictum from the Commission?-`and would render any athlete or official involved liable to life penalty thereunder'. I am not asking for that of course. I do not have the knowledge of what is fair and what is unfair in terms of discipline, but certainly something is required.
I asked Mr Crosswhite who, I should say, is only the Acting Executive Director, what else was intended and he said:
I am not aware of any further action planned by the board on the matter.

Then I asked him about Mr Bowman. At the time Mr Bowman was the Australian Institute of Sport's Company Secretary. There are a number of matters that affect Mr Bowman, not the least being that, as a senior official of the Australian Institute of Sport, he knew of the Jane Flemming urine substitute incident and did nothing about it. He did not inform the Board, the Director or the Australian Amateur Athletic Union. He sat on it. When he was asked why, what did he tell us? He told us that it was because Flemming was representing Australia and not the Australian Institute of Sport and that the substitution incident was a matter for the Australian Amateur Athletic Union and not the AIS. Now I ask you, Mr Acting Deputy President: What chance have we got of discipline if an athlete goes into an event on taxpayers' money from the Australian Institute of Sport but she is representing Australia? Do I take it that from now on any student from the Institute of Sport who represents Australia at any international event has a different set of rules from those representing the Australian Institute of Sport? I should hope not.

That is not the greatest sin of Mr Bowman. Mr Bowman gave evidence before the Committee. I remind the Senate that Mr Bowman was the Secretary to the AIS at the time. The Committee concluded on the evidence that taxpayers' money was used by the Institute of Sport to purchase anabolic steroids under the guise of food supplements. The person primarily responsible was one, Mr Lyn Jones, and Mr Wardle also must have had knowledge of those circumstances. We found a receipt which just happened to have the wrong State on it. Bova Chemist is actually in New South Wales but the receipt had Victoria on it. You would hardly think the chemist would get his State wrong. Mr Bowman did not authorise it particularly but he was essentially responsible because of his position as secretary. He was asked how could he explain that. Paraphrasing his evidence, he said `Perhaps the person who wrote it out had had a bad night before'. That was his regard for a forged receipt which clearly demonstrated embezzlement of taxpayers' funds for the purpose of purchasing anabolic steroids. The Committee noted:

Mr Bowman had had no personal involvement in the approval of the payment of the $90 receipt, supposedly for Colin Bova Chemist but said by Mr Bova not to be from his pharmacy. Mr Bowman noted that the receipt was for a small amount which had been approved under `a proper delegation' and was more concerned over this than over the fact that public monies could have been misappropriated.

In other words, he was more concerned to say, `It was only $90 of the taxpayers' money and it had been officially and properly discharged'. What concerned the Committee was that we found cases where paramedical supplies, contrary to the guidelines, had been purchased without appropriate authority. The Committee's report goes to state:

The Committee was more concerned that Mr Bowman had not sought to closely examine the contents of the Price Waterhouse report prior to his appearance before the Committee, given that much of the substance of the report's adverse findings directly related to his activities as the then head of finance administration at the AIS. The Committee finds that Mr Peter Bowman has displayed disregard for the proper public accountability for the expenditure of public monies inconsistent with his former position as Company Secretary and Administrator of the AIS.
The finding of the Committee was:
The Committee recommends that the AIS investigate the approval of medical supply purchases without medical officer authorisation, contrary to AIS policy, with a view to disciplinary action.

The truth of the matter is that in respect of Mr Bowman absolutely nothing was done. Recommendation 12, the one I have just read, of the Senate Committee's report, in relation to the Commission stated:
. . . accepted the recommendation of the Chairman and the Deputy Chairman that disciplinary action was inappropriate in respect of the approval of the then AIS Ltd's company secretary . . .

That is, Mr Peter Bowman. It was judged that he be not subject to any disciplinary action whatsoever. Mr Bowman was involved in the Jane Flemming case; Mr Bowman was found to have been derelict in his duties and responsibilities. He was an appalling witness. He did more damage to the Institute than almost any other witness. I thought he treated the whole business with contempt, and he has not even been censured. He has barely been spoken to.

One of the findings of the inquiry was that Mr Jones and a number of coaches and athletes were bringing anabolic steroids into Australia quite freely and that they were wearing Australian uniform tracksuits when doing so. One would not imagine that at the Customs barrier they would have been seen as prime suspects for carrying illegal drugs. So they would have been able to get through easily. They would have been encouraged by their coaches to wear their Australian blazers and tracksuits so that they would look like the Australian ambassadors that they were. We discovered that thousands and thousands of these drugs were coming through in that way and our recommendation was that the athletes and coaches no longer be considered as a low risk. That is sad but it is a reality; they are just no longer a low risk. The tragedy is that this has tainted all athletes. But there is no other way one can handle it.

Apparently the Australian Customs Service has taken our recommendation with more seriousness than has the Board of the Commission because an article in the Daily Telegraph on 16 September states that Mr Bowman expressed some very real indignation at the new responsibilities embraced by Customs. The article states:
He said it had reached the stage where athletes returning from overseas events were asked by customs officers where they kept their steroids.
Mr Bowman has just returned from leading a team of athletes to the World University Games in Germany.
He said when the delegation arrived in Sydney a customs official conducted a random search of one athlete and jokingly asked him to take his steroids out of his bag.
The officer had then implied that perhaps the coach had all the steroids.
``Our athletes took it pretty badly'', Mr Bowman said.
``They didn't see the joke in it at all''.
``We are quite convinced the majority of Australian athletes would not touch steroids''.

I do not make any judgments about the flippant conduct of the Customs officer. I would have thought under those circumstances that it was probably a relief for an athlete to have been frisked by a relaxed, frivolous Customs officer rather than one who showed all the pomposity and arrogance for which civil servants are renowned. But Mr Bowman was not complaining about the officer's conduct; he was complaining about his character. He was complaining that the athletes had been questioned in the way that we had recommended. So much for Mr Bowman's regard for our findings! Mind you, he must have been feeling pretty comfortable at this stage, having got off scot-free himself.

I opened my mail and found a copy of the Illawarra Mercury for 16 September; it does not often comes across my desk as it is not compelling reading for someone from Western Australia. But on 16 September, the same day, Mr Bowman was in Wollongong. I took the trouble to speak to the journalist and asked him to read his notes out to me verbatim. The newspaper headline was `Drugs inquiry ``rubbish'' claims' and the article began:
The Institute of Sport track and field director-
note the title `track and field director'-
Peter Bowman yesterday said that a lot of evidence given at the Australian drugs inquiry was a load of rubbish.

I have since asked the Acting Director whether he had called Mr Bowman in and asked him which pages of the transcript, which evidence, which witnesses, which occasion, which circumstances had led him to make those profound but public comments as the track and field director. Mr Crosswhite told me that he really had not discussed those sorts of matters with him. He just referred him to the fact that it was against the policy of the Sports Commission and the direct guidelines agreed to by the Commission as to the making of public statements. We can see that the Board does not care much for the findings in respect of Mr Bowman and why he is not too concerned. I asked Mr Crosswhite-I will not read his evidence out-whether in essence he had read the transcripts, whether he had read the evidence. He started off by saying, `Yes, some of it'. I can only assume he was referring to that part that affected the Institute of Sport. That is not unreasonable. Then I asked him whether he knew anything about Bowman's relationship with the Jane Flemming affair and her conduct. He said:
I was not aware of that, Senator. I am not aware of that.
He said that after having told me he had read the transcript and the evidence as it related to Bowman. I said:
But have you not read that part of the transcript that refers to Mr Bowman's evidence?
He said:
I probably have, but I am not aware of it at this point of time.
I said:
But that is clearly in the transcript. He says that himself.

So Mr Crosswhite said he had read the transcript. First of all, he could not remember it, he was not aware of it, but then he said he had read the transcript. I asked him further about Mr Bowman's knowledge of the matter and he seemed thoroughly confused as to whether he knew about it or did not know about it. In fact his evidence was absolutely appalling. I was moved to say, perhaps unkindly in retrospect, that if I had closed my eyes it could have been the past director, Mr Harvey, giving us evidence. He was a brilliant civil servant, I thought! I have to say that it gives me no hope for the future.

Finally, I touch upon the question of Mr Harry Wardle. Mr Harry Wardle did not even get a mention in the Board's report to the Minister. What of the Committee made up of Democrat, Liberal, Labor and National Party senators? What did it find about Mr Harry Wardle? It found he was Mr Jones's sidekick. The Committee's report stated:

The Committee accepts the evidence that Mr Jones supplied and administered anabolic steriods and other banned substances to athletes at the Australian Institute of Sport and believes that these drugs could have been purchased using public funds, as discussed in Chapter nine.
. . . the Committee believes that it is necessary to recognise that these activities of Mr Jones could not have been carried out without the full knowledge and co-operation of Mr Harry Wardle . . .

What did the Institute of Sport do about that? Absolutely nothing! We also noted the findings of the Institute's own lawyers in respect of claims of use of drugs in sport at the Institute. They drew the conclusion themselves that Mr Harry Wardle gave evidence that was rehearsed by Mr Lyn Jones. In other words, he gave exactly the same evidence as Mr Lyn Jones to the point where it was obvious to the lawyers that it had been rehearsed. Our general findings in respect of Mr Wardle's evidence was that it was unbelievable, unsustainable. The evidence he gave us directly and absolutely conflicted with the evidence he gave to the Institute's lawyers themselves. Naturally, we did not find particularly favourably in respect of Mr Wardle. I asked Mr Crosswhite what would happen to Mr Wardle. He said, `Absolutely nothing'. He had not even merited a mention in the report.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise those matters because they give me grave concern. Of course, the Minister is not, I suspect, bound by the recommendations of the Board and I understand he has some flexibility in terms of his own response to the report and the findings of the Board. Inasmuch as this inquiry has been bipartisan, there have been no party politics in it, no partisan point scoring, notwithstanding the temptation when we had Mr Dowding and Mr Cain trying to bury us because of their own problems. I hope now at the end of the day that Senator Richardson conducts himself in a way which we would expect from a Minister who is concerned about the findings of an inquiry which are unanimous and to which so far he has, at least orally, given support.

I hope we do not see the Government falling back into the bad old ways of Mr John Brown who went on Channel 9-not having read the transcript, not having read the Hansard, not visiting the Committee, not speaking to the Committee, not listening to any oral evidence-and saying in his gung ho, cowboy way that the Committee was a waste of time, that it did not find any substantial evidence and that it was all a lot of baloney. All I can say is: I can now understand why Mr Brown lost his portfolio-lack of detail and lack of concern and regard for the truth.

ANSWER.PARA: The letter was part of a campaign by Medical Schools to gain access to new money for research infrastructure which I announced in May 1989 in my Statement Research for Australia: Higher Education's Contribution in the context of the Prime Minister's Science and Technology Statement. They were concerned that funding may be based on a formula which does not include National Health and Medical Research Council (NH&MRC) grants.

In that Statement I announced the provision of $107.5 million over the 1990-92 triennium to develop the capacity of higher education institutions to support high quality research. These funds are to be distributed on the basis of advice from the Australian Research Council (ARC), in formal consultation with the Higher Education Council (HEC) and having regard to three guidelines described in my Statement.
